Hotel right next to Police parking.
Has toilets for 5q & showers for 25q

name: Agua pura el amigo
description: You can refill a garrafon of 20 liters with purified water for 5 quetzal

name: Immigration at Puerto Barrios
description:
Looks like a normal house but has signs to it. About 150m from the boat ramp.
Friendly people.

name: Tropical Hotel
description:
Hotel with clean rooms and friendly staff.
Cold shower, tv and fan.
Q130 for the night in a two beds room. (Singles where sold out at the moment)
Huge Private parking with gate.

name: Yax-Ha Archeological Site
description:
Beautiful Mayan site deep in the Peten Jungle.  See campground entry for road description, but recognize that tourist vans and regular SUVs do this every day.  

The site rangers do an amazing job keeping all the paths clear for walking.  Catching sunset over the Laguna Yax-Ha is a must-do.  Clean and well-being marked bathrooms.  You pay your entry fee at the main gate/military guard station and from there it is 2km drive to the site.  Beautiful pyramids and open plazas, with enough canopy to make it feel mysterious and special.  Lots of spider monkeys and howlers, and in am and evening, flocks of raucous parrots fly overhead.  We arrived 8:30 am and had the ruins to ourselves for two hours before anyone else showed up.  One of our favorite Mayan sites because of the vibe, if not the pyramids themselves, and we've seen most of the main ones in Mexico, Belize, and Guatemala.

name: Parqueo La llave
description:
Es un pàrquing a 50 metros de las lanchas colectivas que te llevan a Livingston (cuestan 35Q por persona) , nos cobraron 40Q por dejar la camioneta el dia, por el mismo precio nos dejaron quedarnos a dormir.
Está lleno de niños con muchas ganas de jugar!

It is a parking where you can leave the car (40q a day) during your time in Livingston. They permit us stay overnight for the same price. The parking is 50 meters far from the municipal port to Livingston ( 35q each way pp).

name: El Rincon Del Tata Cafe
description: This could arguably be the cafe with the best view in the world.  At the top of a mountain surrounding Lago de Atitlan, we sat on a patio overhanging a cliff, looking out over the lake.  Coffee was good.  We each purchased the promocion, which was a piece of pie and a coffee for 15Q.  We could have ordered one slice.  They were large, and pretty tasty. Bathrooms were nice and clean.  No wifi.  Friendly service.  Great little pitstop on HWY 11.  If you're here on a less cloudy day, please post updated pictures! We'd love to see them!

name: la blanca
description: la blanca ruins. No signs anywhere so thought I'd share the location. decent dirt road from highway to here. care taker seemed very happy to have a visitor. took me on a tour or the ruins, very nice spot. No admission fee, gave him a tip which he really appreciated. could probably spend the night parked beside the road, although not much here.

name: El vagamundo camping antigua
description: Motorhome parking, restaurant, sanitario dump station, rent a car, rent bike, rent motorbike, laundry, travel agency, security, privet bus service ,guide service, wifi free, eco environment, pet friendly, a little outside of town.

name: Uno gas station parking lot
description: We asked and they let us overnight in a corner of their parking, next to water! Really noisy street but safe.

name: Back road pull off in the La Minas Mountains
description: We found this place on a whim after turning left off the CA-9 toward the Puebla of La Estancia de la Virgen.  We took the main road through the town, making a small detour where the road was damaged.  Following a rough (but manageable in 2 wheel drive) dirt road we were hoping to find a nice, quiet and flat place to stay for the night.  WE DID!  About 400m from the fork in the road that will take you to the iOverlander spot of Hotel El Olvido there is a large, relatively flat pull off on the left hand side of the road.  You can't miss it.  It looks like the locals use it for a quarry for gravel, because a large part of the mountain has been dug away here. There is a large telephone poll on the top of it. The wind was a nice reprieve from the heat and we had a nice view of the moon rise and the lights of the villages below us.  The road got more traffic than we expected. Several locals drove by in trucks or on motorbikes (and horseback!), but no one stopped by and - more importantly - no one bothered us.  At 7am some cops came by to ask if we were ok, if we needed assistance or if we were bothered.  We said no, that we were fine and that we'd be moving on that morning anyway.  They gave us their card and said if we had any trouble we could give them a call.  4056-4116. The cops in Guatemala and Mexico continue to amaze us!  Be aware, you are in bug country. It was crazy in the morning when we woke up (fine at night with the wind). Make sure you're wearing protection! Big rigs should be fine at the site, but may have trouble squeezing through the town's narrow roads.  No generators please, let's keep this place peaceful.  Of course there is ROOM for tents, but use your discretion.  We were fine, but a tent seems more vulnerable.

name: Coleman Propane Tanks at Akí
description: We finally found a store to buy our 1lb propane tanks at Akí. They’re quite expensive (Q70 per tank) but coming from the north (Belize) this was the first possibility after Flores (but there they were sold out). The store is in a nice shopping mall with a lot of shops and a good equipped supermarket.

name: Mirador Tajamulco and Tacana
description: Huge pullout on road between Ixchiguan and Tacana.  Amazing view of Volcano Tajamulco and south down the line of volcanos.  Big flat area to dry camp fairly well hidden from road so you can get the sunrise on the mountains and highlands.

name: Servicios Lopez (Julio)
description: Great mechanic here named Julio.  He worked on my Tacoma both when I was heading south and then also north.  Good service, punctual and very reasonable prices. Highly recommend.   Tell him Daniel says hi from Canada.

name: Autorepuestos RD
description: Very good parts shop where they also install you the part you have bought here.

name: La Galeria Del Zot'z Cafe-Bar
description: This place might just have the cheapest happy hour on the island.  When we walked the ring road, the cheapest price we could find was two cocktails for 20Q.  Here, they had a selection of cocktails priced at 2/15Q!  There's no view and no outdoor patio, and it's a little dark inside, but if you're backpacking/overlanding on a budget you really can't beat the price.  Not to sell this place short, it is quite nice inside with local art prints on the wall.  Their menu has a range of Central American and North American cuisine. We didn't eat, so we can't comment on the quality of the food. The mojitos were small (like the size of a rum and coke you'd get in an American joint) but boozy!  The menu pic included is just a sample.  Their full menu is much more extensive.

name: Shell Gas
description: First gas station after crossing into Guatemala at El Ciebo. Has diesel.

name: ATM Santo Domingo
description: We tried all ATM and cajeros in the center and there was no way to withdraw from a Canadian and European card (visa & Mastercard), this was our last resource and worked out smoothly. Don’t miss a quick tour in the ruins within the hotel

name: Hotel Real Esquipulas
description: A small hotel,  bargained on the rooms for us. We got two double rooms with balconies for 37$US for both rooms. Cheap. There was secure parking but for smaller vehicles. We parked right outside the front door where the night security could see the van. There was no A/C but the breeze kept us cool the entire night. There were other hotels around but 10 times more expensive.  Clean.

name: Osteria de Francesco
description: Upscale Italian bistro a bit above the typical Overlander budget, but sublime dishes for a treat or special occasion?  We loved the pasta siciliana and pasta with baby octopus.  Pet friendly....nice lawn setting and open air shade under umbrellas and roof.

name: Showers at Shell gas station
description: As said, free shower located on the side of the building. Cold, but quite clean!

name: Servicio mecanico el esfuerzo
description:
Luis has a small mechanical workshop in a excellent conditions. He had 20 years a VW T1, he know about old VW. He help us a lot with our VW T2. He and his wife love travellers, the help you a lot!
Very recommended

Luis tiene un pequeño taller muy preparado, nos ayudó mucho con nuestra vw combi, el tubo durante 20 años una T1. A el y a su mujer les encantan los viajeros son super buena onda.
Super recomendable!!!

name: Smokin' Joes' Butcher Shop
description:
Opening hours: Tuesday-Friday 9am-4pm.

This places sells all kinds of meats and cheeses at reasonable prices. Great variety, looks clean. Came highly recommended by the owner of a burger place when we asked him where we could buy meat. He said that most smaller supermarkets in town get their meat here and then sell it in their stores.

name: Restaurante Colinas del Cotzic
description: Beautiful new restaurant in the little highlands town of Ixchiguan.  Very nice owner lets you camp on a flat place aside the restaurant (steep but short and straight drive) or on flat pullout by the synthetic futbol court (chained for security).   They plan bungalows in the future.  Amazing views of Tajumulco and Tacana.

name: Gas station
description:
A gas station with a shop, a restaurant, bathrooms and a clean cold shower.
Took a shower for free, not clear if payment was required.

name: Multiservicio Superspeed
description:
We had some problems with our motor generator, and got it fixed here. Good job. 

You can also do alineación, cambio de aceite & some other stuff, nice guys, recommended!

name: Todo Riesgo
description: Todo Riesgo: insurance for my motorcycle 230Q. I saw the brand closed to Tikal so i searched in Guatemala city. Need passeport, vehicule paper and TIP. They do the copy! Can pay with cash or card (but card not with machine, you write all information in a form numero... and they do it by internet) don’t like let my info so pay in cash. Really friendly. Entry is a metal gate.

name: Secured Parking
description: Secure Parking near the cathedral for 1$ per hour.

name: Mayab' Spanish School
description:
we went around town to ask at different schools and this was the best offer we could get. 650 Q per person for one week with 20 hours. one student per teacher. 4 hours per day, from 9 am to 1 pm. additionally there are free evening activities twice a week which you can attend if you like. free coffee and water.
quality of the teachers was good. all of them went to university and speak English. as in every school everywhere, you can get better or worse ones.
big plus: after lessons, you can hang out in the nice garden and use their good WIFI

name: La Flamenca
description: Wow! Nice family serving Spanish-Guatemalan dishes. Prices range from 20-35 Qtz for a main dish. Highly recommend to take one of the “jungle” dishes with ingredients from the palms etc. Mainly vegetarian dishes. Entrance is at the beginning of the uphill road to town just 300m behind the el recreo camp. wide road to park on.

name: Agua Santa
description: We were heading to the mountains and wanted to be sure we were full of water.  Only had two gallons to fill and they gave it to us for free.  7Q/garrafon otherwise...

name: Parking lot of Banco Industrial
description: We spent the night on the parking lot of Banco Industrial. We had a dodge grand caravan with a camper setup at the back. We paid 10Q to a informal security group to watch the car until 1am. Everything was alright and we slept well even if it was in the middle of the city.

name: Guatemala Climbing Project
description: A cool climbing area right next to lake Amatitlan. Super nice climbing with lot of route for all levels. The entrance is by the small tienda Caseta Pepsi, the guide book said 5Q fees for entrance and another 5Q for parking. We actually paid 10Q and left our bikes in the tienda. Please say hello to the old man Julio Cesar. Super fun place, almost no one during the week and most people during the weekend.

name: Taller Rojas taller de vw
description:
This is a VW especialist mechanic, if you have a combi T1, T2, T3, T4.... or a bocho go there, he know everything and he help you a lot. Very honest guy. Also he can recommend you another mechanic depending the car you have.

Este taller está especializado en VW. El hombre es un experto. Sí tienes una combi T1, T2, T3, T4.... o in bochito no dudes en ir! Te ayudan mucho y es súper honesto. También te puede recomendar un taller depende el coche que tengas.

name: SKIPY car glass shop
description: Changed my front glass here, $120 US, Ford freestar

name: Welding shop
description: Good and fast welding service for our mufler. They also made a new part to support our windshield cleaner tank. They did all this in an hour for 150Q!

name: Oil change and mechanic
description: We did an oil change for 40Q. We had the oil and the filter with us. It's directly at the main road coming from Lago de Atitlan going to Chimaltenango or Antigua. Nice people!

name: Agua Pura Buena Vista
description: Seen this place while being in a traffic jam so decided to make a spot. Don't know the conditions. Cheers

big gas station with free internet and armed guard, we slept nicely in the car.
you can eat in a cantine restaurant or a little place in front of the gasolines. max is 40 quetzales

name: Gás Station Texaco-Super 24
description:
New gas station. We asked if we could spend the night here and the atendant said it was Ok and ofered bathroom with shower.
Has water and we asked for wifi and got the key.
Also a 24 hour minimarket so you can buy your stuff.
The guys here where very gentle. Located at the left side of the road when you come from Honduras to Antigua. Good place to rest.

name: Parking lot by Tikal's entrance
description: We arrived at 7pm and although the guard would let us go to Jaguar Inn, we'd need to come back at 6am here to buy tickets losing 40/50 minutes the next morning. We asked if we could stay overnight in the lot on the left to the entrance and the guard of the restaurant said OK and he is looking after the place during the night so it was safe, super quick to get tickets being the first in line and free

name: Gamboa Place
description: A good way to encounter Garifunas ! This is a very small restaurant with fresh foods. All his prepared when you order. Owner is lovely and you can discover Garifunas village just next to it. An amazing experience, if you want to enjoy Livingston.

name: Mar Marine Yacht Club
description:
It’s a Marina with hotel, restaurant and huge parking for RV. 

A good option in Rio Dulce for bigs rigs. Right on the Rio Dulce, there is a clean swimming pool, laundry, toilets / shower and 24hours guards. It’s rather quiet for Rio Dulce (note that there thousand of trucks cross this village and bridge) But was rather correct for 2 nights . 

Parking is big with vegetation. You can reach the village in walking through the bridge in 10 minutes. There is also a « Lanchas » service next door, that offers great tours on Rio Dulce and up to Livingston (either collectivo or private tours). 

You can also refill your tank with water and have electricity. You will also probably meet couple of travelers traveling by boat as it’s a Marina. Overall very good, owner speaks English. 

For big rig we pay 200Q. It will be less for smaller one.

name: Lanchas Tour on Rio Dulce and Livingston
description:
Kind owner that offers great tour on the Rio Dulce and up to Livingston.  From there, you can either book a collectivo or book a private tour. 

In collectivo, it’s 200Q / person for a tour. This tour will bring you at the main interests in Rio Dulce : Castillo de San Felipe, birds Island, small villages, Agua Caliente, amazing cave & Livingston. The tour last 2hours up to Livingston. Departure is early (TBC around 8 / 9 am). 

If you book private tour you can personalize your trip and add other place such as cascadas at Izabal Lake... 

If you go to Livingston, you should visit Garifunas village (IOverlander spot highlighted) to discover the real village. Food is excellent and people so kind. 

Overall lanchas tour was great ! With good guide.

name: Hotel El Pacifico
description:
With our 3,20m high rig and 2 dogs, this was our only option in El Paredon & we were turned down by 5 different places. 

Luckily, the place is lovely! Parking is a very basic gravel lot (would fit 3-4 rigs with leaving enough space for guests). Price is 30Q per night which is by far the cheapest in town we could find. Dogs are very welcome, they have 3 of their own. Bathrooms, cold (but nice!) shower, awesome pool and chill out area can be used. It also has a restaurant, El Tiburon, that does really good but slightly expensive food. We did eat here a lot though as we saved so much on camping and it was very convenient. There is free coffee in the morning, the beach is a stone throw away and everybody is lovely! We really enjoyed our experience and only left after 4 days as the surf was too big for me. For us definitely the best place in town. Quiet at night if dogs are not barking!

We didnt need electricity but there seem to be a possibility to plug in with an extension
cord. Not sure if they would charge.

name: Asamblea se dios
description: You can refill your garrafon here for 15Q per 20L. You can come by car but streets are narrow so I walked from the main square. Bang on the front gate so someone comes for you.

name: Gas Station Linda Vista
description:
New place on way to Cobán after Cunen. Cold and free showers. Has a litlle market that closes at 11 PM. Also fastfood. We asked for wifi and tje girl at the cashier gave us the key. Has a big place behind the station with a little playground for children.
Can be a little bit muddy with rain.

name: Flowas Place
description:
[ADMIN NOTE: Owner posted location. Not yet iOverlander verified]

bungalows with shower and private toilets, or dormitory type, location tents, located feet in the water on the Caribbean, Flowas Place offers a restaurant held by a French, possibility of volunteering if necessary, wifi available, relaxed and simple atmosphere, surrounded by nature. livingston is like an island, no road access. You can reach us by phone or by wattsapp at +502 41939861. Nice to see you, Vanessa and Anthony

En los bungalows con ducha y baños privados, o en habitaciones compartidas, ubicadas en el agua en el Caribe, Flowas Place ofrece un restaurante organizado por un francés, posibilidad de ser voluntario, wifi disponible, ambiente relajado y sencillo. Rodeado de naturaleza. Livingston es como una isla, sin acceso por carretera. Puede comunicarse con nosotros por teléfono o por wattsapp al +502 41939861. Es un placer verte, Vanessa y Anthony

bungalows avec douche et toilettes privées, ou type dortoir, emplacement tentes, situé dans les Caraïbes, Flowas Place vous propose un restaurant tenu par une française, possibilité de volontariat, wifi disponible, ambiance détendue et simple, entouré de la nature livingston est comme une île, pas d'accès routier. Vous pouvez nous joindre au téléphone ou par wattsapp au +502 41939861. avec le plaisir de vous voir, Vanessa et Anthony

name: Puma Gás Station
description:
Big parking lot behind the gas station. Many trucks pass the night here. Armed guards all night. Also monitoraded by cameras. 
Dirty bathrooms and shower. Non potable water but has energy in the site.
Has a ATM if you need money cash.
Small stores in front to by amenities.

name: ATM-Money
description: ATM cashier at the Puma Gas Station. 24h

name: Riverside camping
description: Beautiful spot next to a calm river. There are some bbq places, but the place looks very abandoned. during the day some locals come to swim, but 50 meters upriver there is nobody. The road from the Mexican border is fine, but after 10k there is a turnoff to Playa Grande and Isquixchis. That one is the toughest we ever did. We came from Isquixchis, pushing our bikes 4,5 hours to cover 15km.

name: Como como
description: Very good Belgian restaurant with delicious homemade fries and a very fine refined cuisine. Correct prices and very friendly service. Warm atmosphere. Nice patio. An address not to be missed! Belgian beer 😉

name: no name
description: 5Q per kg left our clothes the evening and got them back at 11am the next day

name: Tropicana hostel - for volcano acatanengo tours
description: this is a hostel that we didn't stay at so I can't recommend it for accommodation but we booked our overnight hike to volcano acatanengo with them for $60usd pp and it was an incredible experience. their guides were great, company was awesome, decent food was provided (two breakfasts, one lunch and dinner) tents are already set up there so you don't need to lug tents or sleeping bags up the volcano at altitude! these guys were the best value we found and we had a wonderful time watching volcano Fuego explode throughout the night. would definitely recommend them.

name: Conejo Mechanic
description:
Conejo is the nickname of Alberto the mechanic that we where guided to by Ernesto owner of a Restaurant nearby the lake Peten Itza.
We had some problem with our gear box in our car a Kia Sportage SUV.
He was recomended by several people and also Romulo, Ernesto's neighbour
The place is not so good looking but Conejo and his family recieved us like part of his family.
We worked at the car at a saturday and had to wait some spare parts coming from Guatemala City.
We stayed for 5 days living with Alberto and his family. Wonderfull experience. A real family experience.
Camped at the yard. Little dirty and dusty but had no other choice.
Alberto Conejo and his wife offered bathroom and shower and evem kitchen to prepare our meals.

If you have an mechanical emergency go to Conejo. You will also make a new friend.

His cellphone number is: +502 5357 1783

name: trailhead to salto de chilasco
description: the parking to the trail-head. we asked a few locals and they said it was fine to sleep here. had a very quiet night. when we drove by the ticket office it was closed but the guy came here later and sold us tickets for the next day. 25q pp.

name: intergas
description: I stayed one night in this gas station without any problems.

name: In Front of a Gas Station
description: We arrived late and couldn't find another place. Quite and a local say it's secure. Flat area but no facilities. The gas station is closed during the night

name: Shell gas station
description: This shell gas station allowed us to stay for the night, super nice people. There’s a bathroom, and a little shop, but nothing else.

name: Shopping center
description:
Stayed on the parking here for one night, just to sleep. Nobody bothered us.

Enough places around with a bathroom and WiFi.

name: Guatemala - Honduras border
description:
We crossed here from Guatemala into Honduras.

On the way to the border no helpers approached us, perfect. Getting to the first check point I stopped and one guy approached us but never saw him again as I told him I didn’t need help.

I went to the guys in the little booth and asked them if they could cancel my TIP. They thoroughly checked if I really wanted to cancel or if I wanted to return, seemed like they really cared. Some of this was with Google Translate since my Spanish is minimalistic and their English non-existent, again they put effort in helping. We needed two copies, which we could make across the street for 1QT per side (two pages double sides = 4QT).

Checked VIN, stamped, had a nice chat (hence; I practised my Spanish) and we drove on.

About 2km down the road there’s a bigger building, Guatemala and Honduras are together in one office here, worked out well.

But as we got closer there was a gate, two guys in what seemed a uniform and many around them (including the ones operating the gate) without. I didn’t trust them as they asked for papers and they didn’t open the gate, I reversed.

The one guy who asked me for papers followed me and I “explained” that I just wanted to pass through and wanted to do the paperwork inside. Now out of a sudden the gate could be opened (operated by non-officials going off their uniform).

We were asked by a “helper” (who spoke decent English) if we really didn’t want help and we kindly declined his offer. At least he was straight forward and pushy.

Park behind the gate, went inside, got stamped out of Guatemala and stamped into Honduras at the cost of $3 paid in American cash. (Local currency would also have been possible.)

Next the TIP, which was done by the guy who I didn’t trust outside and I apologised for my behaviour and explained the situation was confusing.

He collected copies, and started filling out paperwork. Somewhere along the line he mentioned we had to pay $35 per bank, but the bank was closed (since it was night time) and I needed to transfer online. I said no problem since I have internet (Google Fi) and asked where I should send the money to. He said it can only be done with a local bank and he wasn’t  able to accept cash.

There was a guy who he introduced (local) and he could transfer the money for me and I pay him in USD cash. I accepted without asking his commission. All the paperwork done, stamped and signed, I asked his commission.

With the help of Google Translate he said $50, I refused. Then he said $15, I refused again. He tried to explain it was his “work” and I told him it wasn’t an acceptable percentage.

With the paperwork done, now out of a sudden it was possible to pay the guy in cash, who we paid $35 and all was done.

So be careful, they tried to rip us off working together, luckily didn’t work.

The Guatemala officer checked VIN, collected the sticker from the windscreen, stamped two copies and off we went.

name: Restaurante Cafune
description: Amazing, cheap Brazilian-Asian fusion restaurant! Maybe our favorite food in Guatemala! Think it was 25-35Q with drink. Staff is extremely friendly/helpful and gave outstanding service. From southeast corner of parque central (near Catholic church) walk towards all the street food vendors - you will see stairs that go down (and south). Down one flight of stairs you will see a band shell on your right side. Walk to the right before band shell and restaurant will be on right side in the corner under the street above it. Locals told us the owner is chef from an upscale restaurant in Xela - he left to open his own place. Best value for a meal on our trip - went twice!

name: Faulty gas station
description: They pump measurement on this gas station is wrong or they didn't start from zero. The pump displayed a larger value than the capacity of the vehicle by several gallons and we were not empty when they begin pumping.

name: Texaco parking lot
description: Clean gas station with a large gravel parking lot, friendly attendees and the nicest bathroom that I have seen in all of Guatemala. Informal camping may be available

name: Balneario?????
description:
Nothing special, just toilets and a pool... and space. No limits 
50 Q for 2 people 1 dog and a big camper...

Ok for a night and a bath...

name: Texaco Station
description:
Great gas station with hotel, tienda, car wash and restaurant.  Food in the restaurant is very good and service is fast and pleasant.  
We asked the armed attendant at the gas bar if we could park the night and he directed us to a spot.  There was some night noise, but not continual.  It is close to the road, but we were safe and never felt anything but safe.

name: Comedor Guastatoya
description: Simple homemade food. Very tasty and affordable. 25Q for lomo de res with rice and a salad. She also served us tea on the house. Would recommend!

name: Casa Blanca Hotel, Restaurant and Bar
description: Lovely property with good restaurant, bar and rooms available.  Big yard for campers, please inquire in restaurant about camping, but you should be self contained.  We had dinner and breakfast.  Service was very good. Food was good value and good portions.

name: Veterinarian Petccetera
description:
Much more professional than the other one...

Verry friendly and helpful. .   Also helpful regarding dates de vaccination....

Cheers

name: Natural park Volcán Pacaya
description: There,s a dirt parking lot with pit toilets it is free to spend the night here and very calm and no light at all, from here you can have a guide to go to the volcano and see the lava as it is active, 50 qtz per person entrance, 20 child and 200qtz for the guide and if you want you can go by horse 200qtz more. In the way to the volcano there,s Ester,s house where you can eat good local food for 15qtz with juice and fruit as desert and rent sticks to climb for 5qtz, in the parking lot they ask for 10qtz. You can call or whatsapp her in advance if you want to order food at +50257461242 call or +50240029986 whatsapp. She and her family are really nice and will make you feel at home.

name: Hotel Prados del Sol
description: Having A big grass field for parking, several pools...we eat at the Restaurant and the parking was free

name: V-Hikking Tours
description:
Really Great Local Family.

Elvin Soy López , the youngest son of the family received us like a brother in his house and immediately we felt part of the family. 

They organize tours to the top of Volcan Acatenango, they were born heure and they know so many things about this place.
We stayed one week, helping the father in the fields, the mother in the kitchen with the delicious food preparation and doing dishes/cleaning, and we also hiked up the volcano with equipment to help prepare the new campsites ! And playing Football with all Guides !!

You can park in front of their house, it's really safe and the people of the town are very nice and friendly.

They offer you tours to their Campsite on top of the Acatenango Volcan, with an incredible view of Volcan de Fuego that is extremely active. You can watch the lava explosions all night while sitting by the fire and drinking hot chocolate. In the morning, you can hike to the summit to see the sunrise.

Hope you could have the same experience than we had. The name in the Door is Guias Aprode Tour but they are changing the organization for V-Hikkng Tour.

name: Central 10 Boutique Hostel
description:
Very nice hostel! We stayed 2 nights in the shared mixed dorm. Parking available for small and medium vehicles at site but you must reserve in advance. There are places to park nearby as well for a fee. Some of the amenities include: hot showers, clean toilets, full kitchen, laundry for 7Q/pound, good WiFi, pool, common areas, television with Netflix, and rooftop space. Would recommend! Very clean place and friendly as well as accommodating staff.

Mixed 8-person dorm at 80Q per person/night. 
Mixed 6-person dorm at 85Q per person/night. 
Private room around 250Q per night.

name: Chez Valdemar
description:
Great place to spend time and park your vehicle before going to the volcano Acatenango. 

The family of Valdemar is great, super welcoming and adorable, it was a pleasure to spend 3 days with them. 
They cooked for us and even organized our Volcano Ascension and negotiated the prices.
We definitely recommend this place. There is no real price, you give what you think is right.

name: Laboratorio Clinico Central
description: Labs for parasites done in 40 minutes, $35Q. 24 hours Monday to Saturday but he was open on Sunday until 6pm. Possible lunch 12-1

name: Best Ceviche
description: A seafood cevicheria that was absolutely delicious and affordable. You can get a small, medium or large cup of ceviche ($10, $15, $20). He makes everything fresh and offers shrimp, crab, oyster, octopus and clam. Tostadas are $2Q each. Pets allowed. No WiFi.

name: Dr. Samuel Batz
description: Incredibly personable and knowledgeable doctor. Knows some English. Labs next door as well. He is open Monday to Friday 2pm to 8pm, Saturday’s 2pm to 6pm, but it is possible to call after hours +50256161192. He was able to see us on a Sunday night. Four meds plus consultation was $450Q

name: Creamos Futuros
description: Nonprofit organization working in the cities garbage dump neighborhood. They have a little store selling really cool jewelry, bags, and other sewn products. Everything is made by women who live in this forgotten, high-risk area. The organization works to educate children and support women economically, emotionally, physically, and more. Ask them to for a tour or information on what they're doing. English speakers are available. Not a pretty neighborhood but if you are just driving here during the day you have nothing to worry about. You will see a gate at the coordinates, tell the guard you want to visit Creamos and he will let you pull in. Great way to learn more about Guatemala and the realities of life for many -- and experience some of the things we miss on the normal overlanding routes.

name: Restaurante El Huerto (dog friendly)
description:
Proper restaurant with covered seating where they allow your dog to join you!

Pretty good food too :)

They had wifi but it was down when we were there

name: kaena point
description: youth hostel for backpacker, onsite restaurant and many bars nearby

name: kaena point camp
description: camp park outside, just show your passport and power and water outlet provided FREE

name: Victoria Center
description: Fuel station, hotel and convenience shop.

name: la poza river lodge
description: Hostel and Camping site . on 300 meters of private river and 2 acres of jungle and gardens . dormitory , privates and camping. natural swimming pool onsite

name: Parqueo Amaya
description: Private parking without services. Just meters away from the main shopping street. They let us plug our electricity and refill our water tank (only 30L). Not sure they will allow this every time, but they were extremely accommodating and kind. I guess it is just a question of asking nicely. Safe and quiet, closed at night. 60Q per night for our van and 2 people. Showers and toilets just next door for 10Q and 2Q respectively.

name: Warning. steep road (must have good engine breaking skills)
description:
We just take this road to go to San Pedro de la Laguna.(from the Pan-American road)
We have a Van (19ft), heavy and old. 
I warn you to not take this road. get prepare for a long day.
Try an other one if you have an heavy rig. We spend the all day to go there.
 3 stop of 1 hour obligated because of the brakes. For more info, write me on Insta (arth_journey)

drove with e350 ford and breaking with the engine. we were totally fine. (ninsche1)

name: No name place
description: A guy found us in the street while we were looking for a place to stay. He proposed to camp at his place for 25 Q/p. There is place for hammocks or tents. No place to park to this is more for backpackers. You will camp 200 meter just above the city and the lake, probably the most beautiful view you can find around here. There are peaches, Berry's and bananas in the garden. The only problem with this place is to find it. Now you have the coordinates, the entrance is on the road next to it just near a little shop. From there it's 300m of walking up. Good luck, it worth the search.

name: Estación de servicio Texaco. Para dormir
description: Service station where we spent 1 night. Ample place to park, friendly staff. The bathrooms inside are good. There's no WiFi.  It was good. --- Estación de servicio donde pasamos 1 noche. Amplio lugar para estacionar, personal amable. Los baños de adentro están buenos. No hay wifi. Estuvo bien.

name: Honda Motorcycles Workshop
description:
This is the workshop of the big motorcycle dealership ‚Honda Power House‘.
Their office is about 1km south of here on the same street.

name: Maxi Despensar
description: Supermarket with quite a bit of variety, food, fruits and vegetables, car tires, mattresses and so on... :)

name: Cafe El Centro
description: This is an awesome, old-fashioned style cafe in the center to take a break or pass away the day, with delicious coffee, food, pies, and WiFi. Julio the owner is a really interesting guy, a photographer who is planning to do an Overlander trip of his own, by bicycle from Canada to Patagonia. He will be happy to have Overlanders in his cafe and can tell stories about Guatemala City. He is born and raised in the center. The cafe is also exhibiting great new local artwork each month. Make sure to stop by for a coffee here if you’re while exploring Guatemala City.

name: Centro Veterenario
description:
This vet offers the certificate to cross the border to Mexico...
He charges 650Q .... others in the city 1800 Q.... 
Ricardo is a competent Vet and easy...you are in good hands ... umm your dog is.

name: Shell Plaza Rio
description: Filled tank, asked about parking in the side lot overnight. For 20q had bathrooms, a water hose on the backside of the bathrooms for a quick rinse and a security guard watching the premise overnight. Lit parking lot along the main road so a bit noisy but for the price a great value. The store is under a remodel and has little with the inside closing in the evening but gas is available all night. There are local stores open within 5 minutes walking or you can drive/walk/tuk-tuk (3q) across the bridge to the other side. A large stretch of local shops runs through the day on the other side of the bridge.

name: Hotel-Restaurant-Cabañas Brisas del Lago
description:
Family owned restaurant and a couple of cabañas next to the lake. Shady grassy areas for tents and rvs. Camping 40 Q/person, but negotiable. Restaurant a bit overpriced, but nice view. Quiet and relaxed atmosphere, even on SA, when we arrived.

Road from Rio dulce terrible the first couple of kms, lots of potholes, 15km/h max (but doable without 4wd or high clearance). But then perfect road until this spot!

name: Footbol stadium.
description: We stay for 3 nights, for fixing our frame after very bad road. We tirn electricity, nea church are water pipe.

name: Casa Gaia
description: This hotel has nice rooms to rent and large, secure parking for overlanders. Camping in big rigs is permitted, though the bathrooms close at 9:00 when the restaurant closes. Cobán is a natural stopping point between Lake Atitlan and Tikal. The road from Atitlan is long and slow. Casa Gaia was a welcomed stop for us. We stayed in a room ($45 USD) for the night in the rainy season. Food is reasonably priced and available all day.

name: Hostal Paraiso San Jose
description:
It’s really a paradise! Nice garden with ponds, surrounded by trees and palms.
It’s still under construction, but the finished parts are already so nice, modern and clean! They serve beer and breakfast, meals will come when it’s finished.
Lot’s of safe parking space, maybe they let you camp in your car, as camping in a tent is also possible. 
Dorms are 100q and rooms with bathrooms about 160q. 
If you are coming from the north, take the second gravel road on the left, 300m after the petrol station (the road is not on maps.me, but on Google Maps).

name: Field Mechanic Jose Maria ajú navichoc
description:
Owner of the Cafe Chuasinayi gave us this mechanics number. Helped us find a used rear differential same day and delivered in the evening from Quetzaltenango. Finished install following day. Work took place across the street from the cafe where the space can accomidate a bigger size vehicle. Jose was very helpful and didn't mind me helping out with the work. Even did a brake bleed for us. Very reasonable price for the work done and finished in a timely fashion. Number for mechanic: 33742366 whatsapp
Goes by Chema.
If number does not work ask for Chema the mechanic at the cafe. He does not have a shop so he will come to you.

name: Hotel Iquitiu
description: Secure parking lot. Dog friendly. Small kitchen on site not sure on hours open. Very clean room. Rotating fan on ceiling. Friendly owner & staff. Big rigs would have issues getting in through gate. Great view on top terrace. Coffee and pan provided in morning. Paid 235 for 1 night.

name: Agua Pura La Sirenita
description: Tel. 32004024 Very kind and helpul people! Monday to Saturday from 6AM to 07PM

name: Restaurant (free wifi) and gift shops
description:
Restaurant is cheaper than the Jaguar Inn (beer is the same, 22q).
But there’s free wifi and it‘s pretty fast!
The wifi at Jaguar Inn does barely work...

name: Coaba Farms Store
description:
This place is already in iOverlander as a restaurant but it’s so much more and definitely worth noting. 

They have a small store with all things organic (vegetables, amazing eggs, organic dairy, organic meats-bison, lamb, chicken etc.). They also have body care products! 

They also have a special Saturday market where they offer more vegetables! 

Open 8-4
Closed Monday

P.S.  they have yoga too, so many amazing things here!

name: Antigua Brewing Company
description: Great place with all different kind of craft beers, great food (the pulled pork burger is something else) nice rooftop terrace. Had a great time here.

name: Pets Paradise
description: We found some decent brands of dog food here. Purina and Acana and raw food, very expensive but they have it. They also have pet services for grooming it looks like.

name: Balneario Manantial
description: 20Q pp night, very friendly, clean Toilette and cold Pool and shower. Big rigs are welcome as well as dogs.

name: trail to indian nose (guided start)
description:
this is where u are driven by the shuttle if u book a guided hike to the indian nose. from here it is a mere 30 min hike along corn and coffee plantations.
we took a guide for Q90 pp for the sunrise hike. it is busy with guided groups, but i think for the early morning hike a guide is not a bad thing. by daylight the hike is easy to find of ur own (of course at own risk).

name: Casa Quixote
description:
Casa Quixote in Antigua Guatemala is a home away from home to many travelers. The house has 6 rooms of which three are available to rent all rooms have their private bathroom with hot water. We have a big enough parking lot for 2 RVs at a time also where we can provide cable electricity and water replenishing. The property is located just outside Antigua before entering the city, vast green and common areas in the garden with two toilets for the parking grounds, without having to enter the main house. Also we have a cabin bar to enjoy the company of other travelers share stories and relax. Breakfast can be provided, there is security and the area is calm and safe. Welcome to Casa Quixote

For more pictures look us up on FB or IG as casa_quixote.

name: Casa Santa Clara
description: Nice homestay / hostel in Antigua. Big secure parking, our two big motorbikes even sheltered. Nice and quiet to stay and to rest. Big and really good equipped kitchen, big living room with many couches, big terrace and nice backyard. A little, but expensive grocery in walking distance. Bigger supermarkets, a nice traditional market and the city centre are 5-10 minutes by public bus (1,50Quetzal pp one way). Paid 125Quetzal for a private double bedroom with own bathroom. We have found this place on AirBnB. You have to book via AirBnB, because the owner is just once or twice a day present. The owner Walter is really nice and helpful. Highly recommended.

name: Le kape
description: Hidden away next to the field you can camp on outside the carazon del bosque there is a super chilled cafe. The vibes are layed back and the coffee is top notch! Alberto owns the  of the field were you can camp and his sons run the cafe! Enjoy

name: San Lucas - Playa & boat ramp
description:
This is public parking at the lake front of San Lucas. You pay Q10 per day of parking (u get a receipt). they told us, someone was around all day and night, but didn't see security at night. it felt safe though. some people hanging out till later at night and locals in the morning, but usually that's a good thing in terms of safety.
there are public toilets for Q2 (flush/ no seat) and showers. nice views and moderately flat parking spaces.

name: ATM
description: closest ATM for Paredon on this side of the river. Super 24 store

name: Laundry at central del arte por La Paz hostal
description:
They allow guest to hand was and hang dry their clothes and for a very high fee they will wash for you and hang dry. 

Wash $5 USD per load in a regular machine 
Dry $5 USD per load in a regular machine

name: bad road
description: if u are headed to Acatenango trailhead, it is better to take the CHM11 road from Antigua. even if you are coming from the coast, worth considering doing the detour via Antigua. the CHM 11 is a nicely paved road, whilst this one is a dirt road with many pot holes and washboard surface. totally doable, but nowhere nearly as comfortable.

name: Hotel Casa Jose
description:
Hotel Casa Jose is located at the end of a quiet residential street in Coban. Eliana is the owner and her house is next to the hotel (formerly house converted to provide 4-5 rooms of varying sizes all with private bathroom). 
Found this after a long day of driving using booking.com. Was able to negotiate a rate for two adults and one child (12 years old) - paid 250 quetzales for the night. She very kindly accommodated our request for dinner (25q pp) and also provides breakfast on site for an extra fee. Place is super nice and clean, beds are comfortable, great water pressure and you don't have to wait for hot water. Rooms are themed and we stayed in Las Conchas. Free WiFi which was decent. They offer secure gated parking for one or two cars - our Defender was able to fit. Otherwise parking on the street in front of the hotel. A welcome find after a long day of driving.

name: Aduana Express Aéreo Prorroga vehículos
description:
El trámite es simple:

1) tramitar la Prórroga de la visa Turista en la DIRECCIÓN GENERAL DE MIGRACIONES (6ta. Avenida #311 zona 4 ciudad de Guatemala tel. 2411-2411)
Te dan un plazo igual al original. 
Se pagan 25 dólares

2) con el sello de la prórroga en el pasaporte dirigirse a la OFICINA DE ADUANA que está en el Aeropuerto y se llama EXPRESS AÉREO.

3) Presentar el pasaporte, el Documento del auto y el permiso de Importación y Reexportacion del auto que te dieron en la frontera al ingresar.
No se paga Nada.
La autorización es en el momento.
A nosotros nos dieron otros 90 días.

4) Seguir disfrutando de Guatemala 😊👍

name: Don Lalo la kombi
description:
Excellent place to eat burgers and breads, they also have a vegetarian option, all very cheap from 10Q 100% recommended. Hours of operation from 6:00 p.m. to 10:00 p.m.
---
Excelente lugar para comer hamburguesas y panes, también cuentan con opción vegetariana todo muy barato desde 10Q 100% recomendado. Horario de atención desde las 18:00 hasta las 22:00

name: Volcano views
description: Flat near water. Small beach nearby. Fire pit and wood.

name: Narrow road barriers
description: The city has placed two yellow concrete barriers to prevent trucks passing, but we barely made it through in our g35 (literally less than an inch either side). Anything larger would be stuck and I'd hate to have to reverse back to the intersection with the amount of traffic it gets.

name: Restaurante Ital Espresso
description:
Great little restaurant/cafe with nice atmosphere, friendly staff, comfortable patio seating with a partial view of the lake, and good WiFi. Prices are not cheap but are normal for the area (20-35 for breakfast; 40-50 for most lunch/dinner plates). Not a bad place to rest and read or use internet and have a bite to eat, and enjoy the relaxed atmosphere. 

Also, the husband of the young woman who works here, named Walter, is a local conservationist and guide who does tours to El Mirador. I didn’t take the tour but he is a friend of a friend, buena onda, and seems like he would be a good guide.

name: Market Express
description:
Closest gas to the Guatemala border. 
Spend your extra q’s here.

name: Banco Industrial
description: One of the few (only?) places in the city centre that will change US dollars in denominations lower than $50 with only a passport. The exchange rate is decent and definitely better than that offered by unofficial exchanges. They won’t accept notes in poor condition or written on. They didn’t seem to accept currencies other than USD. Open until 6pm.

name: Border crossing: Guatemala -> Belize
description:
From Guatemala to Belize:

1. Cross bridge and park at white building to your right.
2. Migracion and Aduana of Guatemala is inside white building
3. MIGRACION: get passport stamped
4. ADUANA: hand over TIP and sticker. 
5. Drive to Fumigation and pay accordingly and get receipt (see pricelist in photos)
6. Park in front of green building
7. Migration and Aduana for Belize is inside green building
8. 1st window: show passport + let person know where you're staying. Get stamp in passport
9. Aduana desk ahead of you. Show license, passport and registration. TIP is stamped into your passport
10. Go through door to your right and pay outside at little window for import of vehicle (Moto 15 BZD)
11. Drive through last check and leave border (nobody checked my fumigation receipt)
12. After 100m on the right: stop at little house with orange roof to buy 

All in all very easy and straightforward.

name: El Sazón de la Abuela
description: Pleasant restaurant with great food and friendly owners, at reasonable prices - this was our first meal in Guatemala and if they're all like this we'll be very happy! Paid 50 quetzales for two big breakfasts and drinks

name: Zeta Gas Auto Cuchilla
description:
Fill gas of RV integrated tanks ACME
24 hours open
Quickly service
Highly recommended.

name: Los Cenotes de Candelaria
description:
Getting here: follow google maps until you turn on to the dirt/unpaved road, then follow the white & red signs that say cenotes Candelaria. Google will take you the wrong way if you follow directions after the dirt road. You’ll go through a couple small towns but you won’t miss the signs. 

You’ll come to the entrance controlled by the locals and pay her 50q pp. Tell her you’re camping and she’ll ask how many tents. Since we’re sleeping in the truck she didn’t charge us anything extra. The road up to the cenotes are rocky so a bit of clearance or cautious driving would be best. It was dry when we came but it looks like it could get messy during wet season. 

Camping/parking at the 2nd cenote only. There’s a tienda, bathrooms and some shacks near the initial camping parqueo but if you keep following the road there are parking spots right next to the cenote 2. Absolute beautiful view of the cenote. The campground definitely needs some love but it’s expected with Covid and all. 

Arrived and a couple cars full of Guatemalans were swimming but after sundown we had the place to ourselves. 
We didn’t use the bathrooms or the tienda so I’m not sure what’s up with those but bring your own drinking water & food and enjoy this spectacular place!

name: Restaurante tortas Mila
description: The lady who owns/manages this restaurant/property is very generous to travellers. Behind the restaurant is a big parking space to stay overnight. Even further behind is where there is a water park that is currently closed but located in the park is where showers and toilet facilities are located for use. Would ask permission first if camping is available. This is the second time we stopped here in two months apart from stays. Dogs are fine. Restaurant with free WiFi inside. A drink or food purchase would be courteous. There is also a panderia (bakery) attached to the restaurant. Very tasty treats!

name: Monseñor Gregorio Schaffer Hospital
description: This is a hospital with clean drinking water available - there's a tank with taps where the villagers collect water just to the left when you enter the car park. we were led up to separate solar-powered tank on the roof. No charge for water.

name: Mama Brenda Piscinas Termales
description:
Just down the road there is a Turicentro with natural thermal pools.
Bealtiful place, with trees, especially to stay on the evening and night. Open until 22hs.
They only charged us the entrance (10 qtz pp) and allowed us to spend the night for free in their large parking lot. Very safe, Very nice and very cheap. Highly recommended.

name: Hotel Villa de Arcos
description: Very adequate hotel with secure parking for small to medium sized rigs. Probably nothing over about 3 meters (power lines hang low). Got a room with AC for 175q. Also, just a block from good, cheap street food. Wifi is best closer to reception. Showers are said to be warm, but they are those electric ones and when I turned the switch on the shower head to warm, the water zapped me. Not bad, but I’m not a fan of electricity while in the shower, so just left it cold. ;)

name: Cheap delicious street food
description: Several stalls selling plates of various meats with rice, beans, pasta salad, and tortillas. 15q/plate. I recommend the longaniza. A couple taco stands across the street and tiendas selling big cans of Gallo beer for 10q as well. Great place for a cheap, filling, and yummy feed, plus nice service.

name: Police check
description: Checked our passports, drivers licenses, documents, noted info down on their clipboard. Quick and friendly.

name: Dreamcatcher Eco Lodge
description: Very nice place for a break. The owner speaks English and is helpful. They have a dorm, simple private rooms and private cabin. We payed 200q per night for a private room. Excellent kitchen. More expensive then average, but almost ‘Haute cuisine’. You can park save at the Marina and the hotel boot will pick you up. If you are lucky you can see the monkeys in the trees above you and the turtles underneath you at the same time! From the hotel trips are arranged to Livingston.

name: Cuerpo de Bomberos
description:
Very nice place, very nice staffs. 
we just ask for stay and they agreed and were very helpful, said us that could use water and bathroom,
one kilometer from old town City center. Use the back gate. Free.

name: Comida typica
description:
We stopped there until waiting (1 hour) our defensia on the truck was installed few meters away.

It’s a small comida tipica (which opened the day before we came !! )
Super clean toilets.
Good food and really good prices.
10 Q for the order of 3 tacos (really good)

Enough place to park next or in front of it.

Total : 26Q (3€) para 2 ordens de tacos + 4 limonadas. (see photos)
Definitely worth it !

Come and stop here to eat !

name: Polarizado el chino
description:
Right after the gas station and banrural bank.

Seller of “defensia”, small and bigs.
The best prices we found since we were linking for one in Mexico. 
Chetumal prices are crazy (16500 pesos for one big) here we paid (1500 quetzals) for the same thing, including installation.

Good job.
Done in 1 hour.
Also accept dollars.

To compare, in chetumal for a small “defensia” they asked us 5500 pesos. The same here was 1300 quetzals.

name: Texaco
description: We spend the night at Texaco, super quiet, illuminated. There is a Domino’s and a super 24.

name: Football field en route to Acatenango
description:
Big open field with a football pitch and fabulous views! The valley side has what looks like a water treatment plant in the making and a bit of rubbish - but views of the summit of Acatenango and Volcan del Fuego - had some amazing displays of lava at night! The other side is more sheltered - visible from the road but only just if you park up close to the road side where the ground rises up. 

I imagine it might get busier at weekends, but we had a nice peaceful night here.

name: El Punto - Very good restaurant
description: This is the best local cuisine I have had in Guatemala. We had the Menu del dia, beautifully cooked pork meatballs (kind of) with potatoes, avocado and blue corn tortas. We also had a soup starter... high end restaurant standard food and alll for just 25Q. The service was polite and friendly too. Somehow they call themselves a pizzeria restaurant. They do have wood fired pizzas, they are probably amazing too. But the menu offers more than just that and the standard of food is really very good. Highly recommended and amazing value.

name: Java Tech
description:
The VW Guatemala club recommended Javier, the owner of the workshop! Incredible but as soon as we arrived they began to help us to stop the brakes of our kombi and the homozygous 0km !! Super recommended! Wpp Javier: +50246223245

El club VW Guatemala nos recomendó a Javier, el dueño del taller! Increíble pero ni bien llegamos se pusieron a ayudarnos a dejar los frenos de nuestra kombi y la homocinetica 0km!! 
Súper recomendado! 
Wpp Javier: +50246223245

name: Right by the lake
description: Stayed one night on the side of the street by the lake. Safe and quiet. Asked the owner of a restaurant if we could park, he said no problem.

name: Los Amigos Hostel
description:
Best hostel ever. Great vibe, great people, location is in the middle of Flores so very convenient. 
The food is great and at a reasonable price. Pet friendly and a lot of fun. There's a night lounge after 9:30 pm and we also enjoyed that.
 Totally recommend.

name: Shipping with Seaboard (Corporación Menorha)
description:
We shipped our van in a 20’ container from Guatemala to Cartagena. We have a RDH van (Delica), so this seemed like the best option for us on our way south. This point is the office. 3rd story, gray building above a little pollo restaurant. The contact we went through was Mayden de Ralda. Her WhatsApp number is +502 5698 0994 (normally very quick to respond) and email is maydenderalda@corporacionmenorha.com. Although we got in touch a month in advance, she didn’t need confirmation of what ship we wanted until a week prior to sailing. The correspondence was easy- we sent via WhatsApp a copy of the vehicle title, the TIP, and passports. She sent the schedule for the following 4 weeks, a shipping quote for Seaboard, and the agency quote for themselves. The shipping cost $1003, and agency/port fees $525, so $1528 USD total on the Guatemala side. Our ship was to sail on a Wednesday, so Monday morning we arrived to begin the process, which went as follows.
1. Had everything we wanted to travel with packed up. Once the vehicle is in the port they don’t let you get anything out of it. 
2. Arrived at their office (opens at 8:30) wearing long pants and close toed shoes (hiking shoes worked, but with smaller thin shoes they won’t let you in). Met Mayden and she sent us with Ricardo to take the van to the port, just a block away. We left our bags in the office. 
3. Took with us our passports, TIP, TIP sticker, and copy of drivers license (can leave it all in the van, it stays with you for a while).
4. Ricardo gave us safety gear to wear and we began the rounds of stopping at several places to do lots of paperwork. He took care of all of it, only needing a few signatures. Because there were 2 of us, only the title holder can drive into the port, so the other person will ride on the back of Ricardo’s moto. There are a few stops to make (entrance, shipping booths, weighbridge, customs...)
5. After all the paperwork and shuffling around was taken care of, we left the car in the “bodega” for the night. Ricardo gave us rides back one by one to the entrance where we turned our badges in, got our passports back, and walked 1 block back to the office.
6. Back at the office, we made our payment to Mayden in cash (4069q). There was some confusion as to how to pay Seaboard, because you don’t do that through Mayden, nor the Seaboard office there. However, you have the option of paying that fee at the destination, which is apparently what most people do, and we will too (in Cartagena). The other option is to have with you the thousand dollars cash or thousand dollars worth of Quetzales in cash to deposit into the seaboard bank account. (I’ll report back how the payment goes on the Colombia side.)
7. I’ll just note, all of this took most of the day. We had a couple minor hiccups, so, efficiently, it could probably be done in a morning.
8. Done for the day, all that was left was to wait to hear from Mayden about what time slot we would get to put the van in the container for the following day. We stayed at a hotel just 5 min walk from the office.
9. We got the 8am slot, so we showed up at about 7:40 to the office and again went to the port with Ricardo to put the van into the awaiting container. The port workers drove it in, strapped it down, and locked it up. Took photos of the container number and seal number. This took less than an hour.
10. Back at the office, we got the final paperwork to take to Colombia, caught a taxi to the Litegua bus station in Puerto Barrios, and got a bus back to the city to catch our flight.

Overall, there’s nothing to stress about. The only thing I wish I would have known before was that the process takes 2 days. We ALMOST bought flights for Tuesday, but figured we wait a day “in case anything comes up with the shipping.” Good call. Also, Mayden is super nice, she even bought us a big bag of fruit for our bus ride, and Ricardo was an absolute legend flying around the port taking care of everything. Highly recommend shipping with them.

name: Car park next to Shell garage
description: Appears to be an overnight truck stop - quiet at night from 10ish but sporadically noisy in early morning when the trucks depart. Definitely less pleasant and peaceful than Posada Montaña del Quetzal up the road, but free, safe (patrolled by an armed guard at night) and toilets available in the garage shop - possibly also outside; didn't investigate. An external tap too.

name: Pet hotel and grooming
description: Left our two dogs here for two nights while we visited Semuc Champey. Great service. Paid 100 quetzales for each dog per night. There are smaller kennels available for 75 quetzales. Our small dog got a hair cut and that was also 100 quetzales. Our big dog got her nails filed for free. Both smelled really good when we picked them up! They also sent us pictures daily. Totally recommend! Plus, dogs aren't allowed in Semuc.

name: Agua Pura Santa Marta
description: Filtered Water Q.8 for a 5 gallons, looks clean and sanitary.

name: Shell gas station to spend the night
description: Arrived around 6 pm asked if it was ok to park and sleep in our van, they said ok and that it was safe. Opened 24 hrs, a few other trucks stayed the night as well. Also, there is wifi inside the shell.

name: Dr Max Catalan
description: A very good doctor if any medical assistance is needed.

name: Taller de Herrerio
description: Awesome welding/fabrication shop! My roof rack was weekended by weeks on the beach and the roads in Guatemala were too much. Oscar fabricated new braces to hold the rack in a matter of hours. I searched around town for a welder and this is definitely the best I could find.

name: Puma Gás Station
description: No wi-fi, but good flat place to stop, 24h, lots of truckers stoped at night, felt safe, has showers and toilets but in a really bad condition...

name: Gas Station
description: Slept the night here, safe & quiet. This gas station is not opened 24 hrs, closes at 11. A few trucks parked around, we stayed with another overlander. No problems.

name: Cunen Bomberos
description: Took refuge from the rain at this sweet little fire station. Outfitted with a bed, a beeeeyutiful balcony, and an adorable guy who reminds me of my grandpa. We parked our bicycles in the lower level.

name: Bomberos Aguacatan/Public Parking Lot
description: Small local firestation, big dirt parking lot. Tons of stray dogs roaming about. Ask firestation if you can take a shower or use the bathroom, we did. Lots of trucks, tuk Tuks Park here at night. Tent/RV camping is chill.

name: La Combi
description:
Great place to stop and listen to the stories of Javier and his wife who are both amazing hosts trying to make your stay as enjoyable as possible.

Campground and park , with motocross tracks and children playground. Backpackers, RVs, bikers, welcome! We have fresh water showers, toilets, place to park big enough for big rigs and food service available. Close to border with El Salvador and warm weather all year. Right outside of Chiquimuñilla Km 117

name: Pan Superior
description: Awesome bakery on the street where there are lots of street vendors.

name: checkpoint
description: not much happening. small checkpoint when going from south to north.

name: El Telefono
description:
There is few (two) hostels in this street. Very good vibes, family style hotel/hostel, no dorms but cheap rooms of one or two beds:  <50q pp.
Amazing view from the (green and orange) terrace on the traditional type cemetery, and close to the legendary market. 
Quiet vibes, good for relaxing, friendly owners.

name: Very nice food stand
description: Wonderful and cheap fresh food. Shaded place to sit. Very friendly people. Let us try to make our own tortillas.

name: Don Arturo Gas Station
description: New gas station, great to spend the night on the way... noisy though.

name: Mazatenango Hostal Casa Real
description: Familiar hotel in town . Nice for one night. The family is very friendly. 80 pesos / person

name: Hôtel Texas
description:
Hotel in town , with wifi, swimming pool.
We paid 220 quetzales for a room with air conditioning and 2 beds

name: La fonda de Minchez
description:
BEST FOOD!!! Everyone must stop here! The people are so lovely and the food is made with all the love. Veggie and Vegan friendly. None expensive. There salsa will will change your life. 

Strategically well located restaurant before or after crossing the Guatemala-Mexiko border. Reasonably priced breakfast with a satisfying taste. Good.

name: Punto Cero
description: I waited in this place for a long time, 10 mins, there were people playing cards at the bar and no one attended to me.

name: Veterinaria Tecana Santa Rosa
description: $20 for health certificates to cross the border. $12 for rabies shot. Great and affordable.

name: Hostel
description: The hostal ‘a place to stay’ is owned by Raul and his family. They are the nicest people I’ve met. They a a lot of cats and a rabbit which makes it feel like at home. They are happy to arrange everything (transport, excursions,...) for you for good prices and work only with people they trust. You can use the shared kitchen and they have laundry facilities. A dining and seating area outside, which is cosy. Definitely would stay here again!! Short walk to the city centre! Breakfast included.

name: Happy Fish
description:
Great breakfasts and a crazy good frappucino-choco-banana (espresso-chocolate-banana-ice).

Fast and very attentive staff.

name: Playa Salvador Gaviota
description:
Little bar right at the beach. Great offer of cool beers and coconut (10Q/coconut) and restaurant.
The beach is not that clean but the view is really cool and we had the place almost for us alone.

To reach the beach, you need to take a Tuk-tuk in Livingstone and ask for the “Salvador Gaviota” beach. We paid 5Q pp 1 way and then walk through the wooden bridge and along the beach till you reach the bar.

name: Las Gardenias Hotel
description:
Nice hotel in El Remate, very well located for a day-trip to Tikal and Flores.
Prices depend on the room’s equipement: 150Q/night for a king size bed + fan (no A/C) + TV + private bathroom. I think it was 200Q/night with A/C. 
Spotless clean but beware of the ants if you let some food in your room. 
Each room has a little terrace with table and/or hammock facing the full-of-birds-and-plants patio.
Fast WiFi available everywhere.

The game changer for us: the hotel has a little gated parking for 4 cars just in front of the entrance. We could park our van (2,50m high) there. The gate is closed at night and it feels really safe.

Restaurant on site - count 40Q to 50Q for a main, 30 to 40Q for breakfast. They have really good smoothies too.

Tip: a “señor” comes every day to the restaurant to sell its banana bread and carrot cake. He is there in the morning and often back again around midday. The banana bread is an absolute delight. One whole bread is 30Q. Half a carrot cake is 20Q.

The hotel also organized our trip to Tikal. 125Qpp round trip to the site, with a guide onsite. You still have to add the 150Q pp for the reserve entrance. Outbound at 5.30pm, so you are quite alone onsite when you starts the tour.

name: Hotel Chicago
description: Hotel with 1 or 2 parkinlots for campers. we where able to use the top uf the roof to make fotos of the vulcano Fuego, even during the night. Friendly. Asked Q80 (?). possible to use toilet and hot shower.

name: IxomOn hostel
description:
This hostel is running by a lovely couple with three dogs and two cats. If you're pets lover this is your place. They have a big yard with space for two small van and an open space por one or two big rigs. I took one room with breakfast included, but I think you can manage with them just for camping. It's a little bit far from center (6_8) min by car but it worth the views and peace around. 
I loved the hostel because my dog had a lot of place for running and playing with the other dogs. 
Contact Charlie: +502 5991 6813

name: Taller Libelula (amazing mechanic)
description: This is an amazing workshop. it's located in a quite area and the mechanics are super nice. There is a lot of know-how and tools available.  they were able to open and fix my BMW gearbox of the Land Rover, which is one of the most difficult jobs ever.

name: Tienda main road
description: Small parking lot behind the tienda on the main road. There’s a dirt road right before the tienda where you can park and it belongs to the owner of the tienda. We stayed for one night, the owner is very friendly and asked for 20 quetzales for the night.

name: Hotel Santa Monica
description: Nice, clean, hotel with a pool, wifi, and AC. Cost me $170 QZ. Located right on CA9 in Los Amates. One of the nicer stays I have had in CA. *Wi-Fi only near lounge area

name: Gas station San Carlos.
description: Very old but huge gas station open 24hrs close to the road. We asked the guard if we can stay overnight and he said yes right way. Very nice people. He didn’t ask but I gave him 20 Q and a soda.

name: ATM BANCO DE DESARROLLO RURAL
description: Bank with an ATM to be able to withdraw money.

name: Lavenderia del Rio
description: 20qtz el kilo - good service - we had our clothes the next morning

name: Hotel Terra Maya Showers
description:
Hot showers with great pressure for 15Q 
Considering the 10Q cold showers in Antigua, if you’re near this location. it’s worth it!

name: ASOAVA Acatenango community guides
description:
We rarely do tours, but this is a true Guatemala experience. Catalino picked us up from the tourist police park and took us to his house in San Jose where we slept and had a home made dinner with his family, cooked by his wife.
Before trekking the Acatenango volcano,  ASOAVA offered us direct contact with the guides without an agency intermediating (we felt our money was going to who really deserves it). It was just me, my girlfriend and our dog Pancho trekking, with a guide just for us, not the typical excursion. Once again we were offered home made meals while in the volcano, they offered us jackets, gloves, hats, sleeping bags and a tent with an amazing view to the volcano. The trekking took us 4 hours to reach the campground on the first day. We spent the night watching a beautiful show of lava explosions right in front of us, cooking dinner and drinking hot chocolate around a fire pit. On the 2nd day we woke up at 4am to start a 1h30 trek to the top of the volcano to watch the sunrise while the fire explosions continue! Catalino told us the best way to contact him is trough WhatsApp and Facebook, so we’ll leave his number here 
tel: +502 55004707 
Hope you enjoy it like we did :)

name: Shower
description: Servicio Don Arturo . Hot shower at the gas station, ask to the staff. Free

name: Tito’s Garage
description:
Great mechanic, very helpful and hardworking. Was able to park at the location with no problems for two days, he drove me back and forth an hour away, on two different days. My clutch cable snapped, They don’t have VW bus parts in this part of Guatemala, he was able to find a similar cable was able to find a place to adapt it. Extremely wonderful and hospitable people the family let me use the bathroom/shower and even made me breakfast and coffee in the morning.

All this cost me only 150Q

name: Energía Solar
description: Solar business selling parts, panels, charge controllers, inverters, batteries and more. They also provide consultations, diagnostics and installation. They are kind and patient, Spanish speaking only.

name: Tienda Lolita
description:
The friendly family here allow parking in their large lot for 30Q day. We used this whilst hiking the volcano, and also stayed a night, no problems. Relatively quiet at night, felt safe to leave our vehicle here.

Small shop and delicious tostadas! (3Q each)

name: Señora María Laundry
description:
We saw Señora Maria washing clothes and we asked her if she could do ours. She washes by hand so you have to give her a little bit of time. Perfect to drop off before going to Tikal and collecting the following morning.  It was really
Cheap considering everything we had to wash, including towels, a duvet and dogs bed!

name: Paseo del Lago
description:
A small park with lake views. The lovely policeman on duty, Freddy, watched our van for us while we were at the climbing area and let us stay the night there (he was guarding the entrance all night). We cooked him dinner and spent hours practicing our Spanglish together, super friendly! 

Note: this road doesn't go through to the north, despite what Google says! only passable on a motorbike.

name: Chichicastenango family garden
description: Nice spot on family garden. Very friendly family. Ask for Doña Ana o Don Tomás. They start the overland activity with us and that is the reason that in this moment only can park an fill water, but in the future they will improve the service. The place is about 10 minutes walking to the market area, is quiet at night, flat and secure.

name: Shell gas station
description: Gas station operates 24/7, small store closes at 7 pm. Loads of truck drivers staying overnight. Simple but clean bathrooms. Not sure if they have a shower. In the evening traffic calmed down. Friendly and helpful staff.

name: Turicentro Vista Hermosa
description: A nice place overlooking the valley far enough from the road to be very quiet. It’s a jardín de eventos with a couple of swimming pools, bathrooms and showers and a tienda and the very friendly owners prepare simple meals for a decent price. The access road is quite rough and steep and there is a height limit of about 2.30 m. For two people in a camper van we paid Q50 (after bargaining a little bit).

name: Parqueo Central
description: It’s a large car parking in front of the church in the town center of Todos Santos. The gate is closed from 6 pm. to 6 am. but it’s not fenced and there’s no night guard on duty. It’s very busy during the day but it calms down at sunset and from 10 p.m. the only noise is from barking dogs all around. Q10/vehicle.

name: Hotel y Restaurante Secretos del Lago
description: Nice place to camping, near a hotel and restaurant, you only pay Q.50, it’s a nice place to camping

name: Jorge y Ronald Mechanics
description:
Honest and excellent mechanics in Colomba. They’ve fixed our gas pump and our differential on our 28ft motorhome. We recommend them on a heart beat, awesome people.
Jorge 5727-6060
Ronald 5460-6774
If you don’t speak Spanish, call Shane at 4657-0812 . He is an awesome American that runs a mission to help the kids in the village getting educated, he will help you and he is a good friend of the mechanics.

name: Rincon Suizo
description:
Grassy spot 25m above the highway.
No dogs barking, no music.
Free
Truck noise did not bother when sleeping with windows closed (it was around 5°C at night)
Female toilets were still open at 22:00, not sure if they ever lock them.

Ask at Caja (restaurant check out) for permission to camp.

Go up on Parqueo 3 which is likely almost always empty except of a Chevrolet oldtimer and 3 cars of employees.

Water Faucets all arround this parking lot. Normal water hose does not connect to them, you need a 1/2 inch male thread.
Next to male toilet is a 'pila'. There is also a big washing machine, did not ask if we can use it.

Little cute hike through the forest.
Playground

We hung out in the restaurant without consuming to enjoy the fire chimneys.

Crepes and desserts of the restaurant are very tempting.

Safe as there are guards on duty and cameras all over.

Restaurant:
Capuchino 15Q
Breakfast 28-55Q
Plates: 26-67Q
Beer: 25Q
Crepes: 40-80Q (gluten free option)
Very professionaly run, Very popular to Guatemaltecia from the City

name: Mecánico Mario
description:
Such good mecanic! The U joint of the rear axel had to be replaced so we met Mario in the middle of the street and brought us here. 
W had to wait for the new piece to arrive so they let us sleep here.

name: Water and Soda distribuidora
description:
5 Gallon Garrafón for C75. 
Its not signed posted but you can see all the soda bottles from outside

name: Mandarina Cafe
description: Mandarina Café is an awesome place co-owned by Australian and Guatemaltec ladies. They have awesome café, gluten free and vegan treats, their breakfast are to die for! This is the place to eat in Quetzaltenango when you are healthy!!!

name: Cruz Roja Purulhá
description:
Very kind people at Cruz Roja. 
Spent a night
I’m a cyclist but there is space for big cars also

name: Street camping outside Hotel Xolotlan
description: We came here just to ask if we could have a shower. The staff was super friendly and told us we could for no price but for a voluntary tip. They wouldn’t tell us how much. Our camper didn’t go through the doors so they asked us where we are staying and let us park outside the hotel, they said it was safe, there are cameras all around the building. We felt safe.We also went for dinner near by and everything was great and No hassle On the street.

name: Aceitera - Oil Change
description:
Isayas charged 50Q for oil change.
He seemend honest and discovered a gasoline leak.

4,73l Caatrol oil syntetic 350Q
Natural 250Q

name: Multiservicios Revolorio
description: I lost coolant, these guys found the leak and fixed it up. they were nice and helpful.

name: La Cabaña De Tío Conejo
description:
Incredible hospitality by the owner Tío Conejo. Was allowed to camp with no issues he even extended a electricity bar to my bus so I can charge my phone, also there’s access to a swimming pool and a small BBQ pit.

Great and helpful host, 5 minute walk from the beach.

name: Finca el Amate
description:
Nice place to camp with amazing views!! The price to camping crazy Q.125 per person. 

Un lugar increíble para acampar, con impresionantes vistas. Q.125 por persona para acampar.

name: Ahuachapan street
