description: Small ATM in a cage. 6$ fee, sometimes doesn't work I've heard, but was fine for me today. Also another ATM (same bank) on the corner inside a restaurant

name: Restaurante Tal vez Mañana
description: 2 floor restaurant, we were allowed to put our tents to lower floor for free and if we buy something drink and eat from the restaurant on the top floor. Local boy shared his internet via hotspot to us. Local beer was 10 quetzals.

name: Boat tours Boca del Polochic
description: Here the lanchas leave for the Parque natural Boca del Polochic. It's a nature reserve and you can see lots of monkeys (rio polochic), birds and manatees in the laguna de izabel. For lanchas you can call Pedro Jimenez (phone number 5122-4637) or ask in the office from the nature reserve at this coordinates (15.5238540, -89.3348960). Boat tour for 3 hours costs 350 Quezales per boat (doesn't matter how many you are, it's like a private tour). We saw several manatees in the lagoon and lots of birds and howler monkeys.

name: Te Quiero
description: nice little cafe with deliciously sweet coffee options and tasty croissants. basically all coffees that aren't plain black, 10q, were 15q for the small and 20q for the large. clean bathrooms and fast wifi.

name: Guatamaya Spanish Academy
description:
This school and homestay offers the best of both worlds- the option to be fully immersed in culture in a quiet, local neighbourhood, while also only a 5min walk from the busy touristy strip along the lake. The view from the classroom is amazing and keeps you motivated during class, and our teachers Rafael and Lorenzo did a great job at keeping class interesting by using a practical approach tailored to our needs. I stayed 2 weeks longer than originally planned, and convinced my Dad to join as well instead of going to Antigua, and we both couldn't be happier. The owner Jose also took the time to organize outings for us, including a cool tour to a nearby coffee plantation, where his family owns one of the plots. Everyone here is clearly very passionate about what they do, and it shows

Best reached through Jose on WhatsApp: 
+502 3332 7888
http://guatemayaspanishschool.org/

name: El Boqueron Canyon
description:
Interesting quick stop (~30mins) on a canoe-like boat paddled upstream by one of the locals through an impressive steep canyon. Also some tables, bano, and small playground by the parking area. Not to be confused with other Mayan area northeast of here with the same name.

Costs:
10q parking per vehicle
10q entrance pp
20q boat ride pp

name: Pozas Machaquila (blue river for swimming)
description:
Cool stop to split up the drive between Flores and Rio Dulce, or vice-versa. Crystal clear river to swim in with a little current that's fun to drift down. Only locals here, no sign for this entrance and totally free. 

On the north side of the bridge from the highway, there's a sign to a different set of pools on the river, with some small palapas and concrete steps down to the river, may have to pay to park here. 

We preferred the pools on the south side of the river because it was fully natural and a bit more of an interesting swimming area

name: Ranchitos del Quetzal
description: Just adding this with the informal campsite symbol as we would have missed this. You can find other reviews by clicking on the hotel icon. It is pretty steep in price, we paid 200Q for two people and a child. But a lovely option if you want to hunt down those protected birds. We were able to camp next to the ranchito/palapa, grill under it and use the tables, electric points and water hose. Wifi was pretty good. The toilets are clean and well kept. We were with other overlanders, some of whom also parked in the carpark and pitched tents in the „tree house“. We participated in a night walk and one in the morning. Lots of orchids and species like frogs, salamanders, snakes, blue jays and of course the Quetzal, if you’re lucky.

name: Vulcano Tajumulco
description: Ask locals before driving up for hikes to volcano if its safe. When we were here today and asked about sleeping up there the locals said they have a lot of problems at the time and its dangerous. You could also here people shooting.

name: Automotriz Byron
description: Our Mercedes 308 had a problem with the ignition coil and the interrupter from the distributor. We couldn’t start the engine anymore. Byron (mechanic) could find and solve the problem. He could even find a new interrupter for the distributor for our old (1981) Mercedes, which is usually a big deal. He also organized a safe place to stay overnight because we couldn’t fit in his garage.

name: municipal camping
description: just before the agencies place there is a terasse where you can put your tent. 4 to 6 tents max. we arrived at 13hr so we can choose the spot and had the chance to be in front of el fuego.

name: Mirador Chuich ok'ok'
description: Excellent place to camp. Secure bathrooms and beautiful view to Atitlàn lake. Grill platforms but they have no grills. Lol. take your grill.

name: Purificadora
description: 5Q to fill our 7 gal tank and they even cleaned our tank for us. Quick and friendly.

name: Azafran Panaderia
description: Takeaway bakery with seriously delicious sweet and savoury empanadas, cakes, and bread. I tried the piña empanada and the banana bread, both delicious. 5 to 6 quetzal each. it's in the mall right in front of the supermarket entry.

name: El Buen Gusto
description: Nice restaurant with 25Q+ breakfast, 35Q+ pizza, 40Q+ dinner (menu pics attached). Fast Wi-Fi and nice bathrooms, nice shady spot.

name: Cerveceria 14
description: one of the best breweries we have come across in a long time. huge campus with grassy areas and many tables. very friendly staff and everyone speaks English. incredible beers and food. prices for food was 65q for a burger to 100q for pizzas and beers ranged from 27-35q. american expats own and brew here and have setup a very familiar feeling American style brewery. it feels like we could be in Pacific North West again and not surrounded by volcanoes in Guatemala. they offered to let us stay in our van for free overnight in a shady area of the parking lot, but no access to amenities once they closed. this place is pretty far out of town with nothing else to do so it was a nice offer but we opted to stay at Verde Eventos that was very nice.

name: Las Antorchas - Swiss restaurant
description:
A very good restaurant situated in a nice patio. The chef is Swiss (from the French Speaking part), proposing delicious Swiss dishes (raclette, röstis, émincé de veau à la Zürichoise & meringues) as well as meat & pizza. 
The food is amazing, the location pretty and the service very good. 
We strongly recommend this place!

name: C4 Comida Tipica
description: Desayuno tipico 30Q, menu del dia 25Q (chicken soup or fried chicken), natural juices 15Q. Good cheap food, fast Wi-Fi, nice restaurant.

name: Embacadero lanchas públicas Tzanjuyu
description:
From here you can go by public boat to the towns around the lake price per person Q25 you can get there on foot or by tuk tuk.

desde aquí puedes salir en lancha publica hacia las poblaciones al rededor del lago precio por persona Q25  puedes llegar caminando o en tuk tuk.

name: Restaurante La casa del sabor
description: Good restaurant right next to the mirador Juan Dieguez Olaverri. We ask the family if we could park in their entrance and they have place for 2 campers they even close the fence during the night for safety. We are too big for the parking lot! The view is beautiful and is nice stop before explore the surrounding!

name: Museum of Paléontologia, Arqueologica de Estanzuela
description: beautiful museum, free with 2 room about Paléontologia and 2 for the archéologic one. Really interesting,  beautiful bones of a mammut and free so if you're going down to Honduras or Salvador, it's good for an 1h stop.

name: Claro Agency
description: Great place to get a SIM and cell package for all of the Americas. It works from Canada to Argentina. They are very helpful and professional.

name: Llama Huehue
description:
Nice little place in the village of Chiabal. Next to the mountains Cuchumatanes! Good place to stay if you want to go hiking. You can walk to the trail.
They have lamas, sheeps and a little farm. The family let us stay there for 15Q. They offered a bathroom as well!
10Q more if you want to visit the lamas.

name: Very steep and rough road
description: Be careful this road is really steep and rough. Lots of hole on the road too. If you don't have a powerful vehicle or if its too heavy, you probably can't do it or just very very slow. Be prepared !

name: River Crossing
description: Beautiful road leading up to this point then turns into dirt road going to a river crossing. It was shallow and no issue for our Ford Transit. Regular cars passed as well. Not sure if an RV would be able to make it though since going in and out the river bed is pretty steep and rocky...

name: Cheyo's Garden
description: 70Q per night. This property is an eco garden with a tiny house Airbnb. There is room to park two RV's in front of the property beside the road, or two cars inside the gate. There are also spots for tents. It is very safe and secure, on a quiet country road with zero traffic at night and minimal traffic during the day. The amenities include a hot solar outdoor shower and outdoor compost toilet, as well as access to an outdoor kitchen with stove and fridge. It is about a 10 minute drive to Santiago Atitlan, and 30 minutes to San Pedro de Laguna. The property has a lovely garden area to relax, it is very tranquil for a moment to rest from the road. You can see Volcano Atitlan on a clear day! It is possible to access the lake for swimming and relaxing, about a 20 minute walk. There are two dogs here, one is friendly and loves other dogs, and the other is chained when the caretakers are not present. The caretaker's name is Cheyo, he is a local Mayan who knows the area well and is very friendly and helpful. He also offers local coffee for sale and guided volcano hikes. We had such a lovely experience here, what a magical place, in the heart of Mayaland! To stay here arrange by calling Cheyo Whatsapp: +502 3326 2086 *note, Cheyo speaks Spanish and Mayan

name: Taller de Mecanica Clinica automotriz Morales
description: A great garage where they do all kind of mechanic work. Electronic and regular mechanics. We stopped to have our brakes checked and Tomas was very nice, serious and helped us right away. He went to France twice so he is used to foreigners. We recommend this place !

name: Hostal El Nawal
description:
Because most of the other hostels in the area have bad reviews I figured I'd enter this one. 

Basic dorm beds 50 qz/night, super friendly host and staff,  cold showers, no WiFi or Tigo mobile signal.  Large parking area that isn't gated, but is removed from the road and in sight of the cabins and restaraunt,  unlike some of the other options in the area. Felt safe parking my bike.  Far enough away from Semuc Champey to be chill, but still close enough to walk, although it is a bit of a hike up and down hill . From this spot you can flag down a truck for 10 qz if you want.  Didn't try the restaraunt on site, normal slightly touristic prices (beer 20 qz, burrito 35, pizza 70). I'm not sure if you can camp in your van here,  as I don't have one I didn't ask,  but it seems suitable. you'll still be advised by the host to have 4x4 to get here,  although the road to get to this spot is generally better than the final stretch into semuc.

name: Farm Santa Eliza
description:
We are the owners of this place. The camping ground is part of an established cacoa farm. 
Phone Number: +502 3100 40 97 or +491604743766 (Whatsapp)

We speak Spanisch, Q'echi, Englisch and German. (All fluent - but different people...)
If you are interested in staying at a place with no tourist. (Exept you in the future) and you want to learn a lot about Cocoa and other plants, you are at the right place. 
Coming from Rio Dulce to Lanquin or vice versa, this i a very nice place to stay. 
For whatever reason, the first visitors came from Germany. (Dino Adventure - See the picture below)
Alhan from Guatemala and Andreas from Germany have started a joint projekt to grow Cacoa and other plants. At the moment we have 8 Hectar under management and we are aiming to go for more. The Farm is build on an agroforest approach. We are very well integrated into the community and at the moment we support a dental project in this area as well. 

Santa Maria de Cahabon is a small pueblo nearby. You will find a local market, very friendly people and a very typical environment. 

We also offer trips to the farms we work with or into the natural park just beginning 2 Miles from our place.

The Place website is the german website for dokeshi. But give us a whatsapp call and you will find out more.

By the way, place is free of charge. Would be happy if you donate to our charity project.

name: Frenos
description: good mechanic. He repaired our breaks and suspension.

name: Hotel y Restaurante Rancho Alegre
description:
Large open parking lot, clean toilet and  electricity.
Eat at the restaurant and park for the night for free.

name: Amazing informal campsite with insane view and fireplace
description:
we showed up here at 2pm, had the place for us, absolutely mindblowing view on El Fuego eruptions. 

$4pp as someone will come pick up money around 6/7pm.

dont worry about being able to do this hike alone, this is just marketing from tour companies. 

INSANE STUFF, most impressive thing I ever witnessed after years of traveling.

name: modern Mayan ceremony site
description: In use daily by locals. Lots of statues and burning of offerings. parking at the front. It's on a steep road but nothing out of the ordinary for Guatemala. free. there's a guy who cleans up and takes tips from locals

name: wifi at mcdonalds
description: free WiFi at McDonald's no password needed open till 10pm. Always busy.

name: Hotel Playa Linda
description: Nice, family-owned waterfront hotel. Hotel is currently undergoing several renovations inside and outside. Features include a private pool, in-room fireplace, pet friendly, secure parking, private garden with beautiful flowers from the region. I got a room with a king-bed and twin (view of Lake Atitlan) for $250Qz for 5 nights. It has surpassed all of my expectations.

name: Hotel Margot
description:
2 people, one double bed. 150 Guatemale dollars
Super secure parking. Parking entrance is on the side street

name: Hotel el Meson
description: Good clean room with 2 single beds and motorcycle parking. They have room for 2 minivans max. Paid 150 Guatemala dollars. Shared clean bathroom. One block away from Internet cafe to print papers. 2 blocks from bank. Had nice Mexican style hotdog from street vendor for 12$

name: LACM laboratories de analisis clinicos Mendez
description: Open 24rh, pcr test. Results within 2 hrs. Cost 1800 Honduras dollars. 10-20us more than others

name: Casa Benjamin Linder Hotel
description: 2 bed clean room with good washroom and shower attached. Paid 20us dollars and parked 2 motorcycles. Ac is extra $13us. Has room for camper but don’t know if they allow. Has tent place but also don’t know if they allow. Free breakfast. Very secure. Large grocery store is 2 blocks away

name: parking front of river
description:
we slept one night here during semana santa. planty of locals at this time but i'm pretty sure there is nobody when it's not vacation time. we paid 10quetzales to an old man (little bit deaf) for parking and ask to stay overnight. he was ok but the next morning he woke up us at 7 am to leave or paid for new day (thanks again to semana santa). we asked also locals living here to know if it's safe place, they answered us nothing appened here. 
we paid 5quetzales more by people to go to the river but when it's so warm outside YOU WANT TO GO TO REFRESH YOURSELF!
nice surprise, hen and chicks found safe place under our truck... there were sooo cute!

name: Hotel Gran Shalom 2
description: Hotel with a large event area and futbol field for rent. We parked in the secure parking lot and was offered use of the bathroom which was clean enough. Free wifi also. Paid 50q per night. Definitely the best thing we found in town after looking for a couple of hours. The local police actually brought us here after asking them for a suggestion. Our 3.3m high truck camper made it inside the gate with no problem.

name: hotel calisso
description: very nice hotel in the very nice pueblo of amatitlan.It is structured like a motel with parking, comfortable bed and great and roomy showers.The price is 125 Q if you arrive after 5 and stay until the morning after or 150 Q for 24 hours.close to the mercado and tasty comedores and located in the city center.

name: Aruma Eco Hostel
description: They allow you to stay in the camper on the parking lot (next to the road). They asked for 30 Q in total (2 people in a truck camper). You'll have access to the toilets and showers. Not secured, but felt safe although the place was a bit noisy due to the road.

name: Hotel Pasada Del Viajero
description:
Decent budget hotel to spend the night. Prices vary from 50Q to 125Q (Single occupancy), see pics for prices. All rooms include fan, "aire" rooms have ac. 

Large secure parking (see pics) with 6 official car spots, but you can fit more. Height restriction of about 10ft.

Tiendas, bakery, restaurants nearby

name: Next to Elektra Supermarket
description: Cheapest parking we found here for the bustling Sunday market. 10 Quetzales per hour. Guarded No height restriction and you don't have to hand in the keys. Big rig friendly.

name: Villas Hotel Jabel Tinamit
description: A bit more expensive but very nice place if you are in need of a few days rest. Secured parking, garden, terrace and patio. Decent wifi. Very nice room. Very attentive staff and great breakfast included. Located minutes from resto and street food and about 1 km from the lake and public ferry dock. We paid 380q per night.

name: Antojitos ???  - Local Restaurant
description: I don't normally add Restaurants but this one deserves to be mentioned. Only 2 different options on the menu (go with the Loma). Only locals the two times we were there. Seating outside in plastic chairs/tables across the road from the lake. There is an option for a small portion for 40Q which satisfied hungry cyclists with the delicious tortillas, papas, y ensaladas. Cervezas @ 8Q - Hard to beat for the lovely but expensive touristy island.

name: Hotel Embajador
description:
The family is very kind, its a fair prize and depending on your choice of room and hotel you may have a lovely view of the surroundings and a good rest!
They may allow you to use the kitchen too.

name: El Buen Pastor
description: This restaurant is close to Hotel Hollywood, which is a great staging location for an early morning crossing into El Salvador. The couple is Erick and Elvirena. They serve delicious pupusas (queso, frijol, chicharrones when we were there) and tacos (res when we were there). Pupusas are Q5 each. Erick kindly walked to the store to get the drinks we asked for. Really nice people and a pleasure to support.

name: Mahanaim Hotel International
description: Great place to stay, especially if you’re riding a motorcycle. 200 Quetzales/night with A/C, cheaper without. Lots of hotels in town, but this one had secure motorcycle parking in back. Walking distance to everything, street money exchangers around the corner. Swimming pool, real nice coffee shop, wifi.

name: Copias
description:
Good place to make copies. 
.....
Un lugar bueno para hacer copias.

name: Cafe Boheme
description: Probably the best french bakery, smoothie place in central America. beautiful and unexpected place in Antigua.

name: minas de sal
description: interesting place were locals gather salt water for cooking on Mondays and Tuesdays around noon. Not a traditional mine but still super interesting

name: Techron gas station
description: Gas station where they were happy to let me overnight when the dark caught up with me. Quiet and very dark at night (power was down after a tree brought down cables nearby) between 9pm and 5am, when the generator was turned back on. Clean toilets and a lovely cold shower, which overnighting truckers were making heavy use of in the evening. Electrical sockets available.

name: InterSport Gas Station
description: All other spots at the Tajumulco Trailhead we're closed when we arrived late. asked at the Gas Station. Owner was very friendly, said the station is open 24h and we can use the open banos. Quied and safe. The whole area seems to be calm and unspectacular.

name: Clinicas Medicas
description: Here is a place with many different specialists- Doctors, dentists etc. Our little one had a very bad stomach bug and we sought advice from pediatrician Dr Vanesa Lemus González. She was very thorough - carrying out a complete health check in addition to the investigation we needed, and we were very pleased. She took samples, had us nip over to the lab to get it examined and an hour later, we were able to consult with her again and receive the right medicine for our daughter’s bacteria. This consultation cost 200 Quetzales. We would highly recommend. Please note- appointment bookings are required in advance.

name: Miratengo II
description: we're in the wrong Route to the ioverlander miratengo campground. at the end of the street was a gate. we asked, If we could stay here for the night. they charged us 50 quetzal. grassy leveled parking lot with Clean toilets and a warm (Electronic heater) shower. Direct Access zu acatenango Trail.

name: Lavanderia Lili
description: 6 Q for libre. Good service and ready in the day

name: Cuevas Chicoy
description:
Caves a couple of kms of the main road. A Mayan sacred site. 
Very cool. The path is a  bit sketchy but ok. 10Q per person entrance fee.

name: Hospedaje Maya
description:
Incredible local family! Most warmhearted people I met on this trip; simply amazing to meet them. They have a room for travelers, serve food and don't tell you a price. So you decide how much to give. Can't say how much I recommend this place!
Jonas also guides you up the volcano, for a third of the price you pay in an agency. They have an organization of local guides, where guides are not exploited as they are with the agencies.

name: Finca Sacmoc
description:
An eco retreat in the jungle north of Coban.
Accommodation,  walks, swimming holes, waterfalls, tubing, a swimming pool. 
A fairly rough road to get here. The owner suggested 2hrs from Coban 35kms away. It took us 1hr on light motorcycles. Possible in cars ,trucks and campers with good clearance and patience .Worth the effort.

name: Casa Madera
description: Great local restaurant selling good simple food at a great price. We had lunch here and came back for dinner.

name: Parqueo Público
description:
The other place is not accepting people sleeping inside the van. So we stayed for the night in this one. It’s safe with a fence. It’s 100 quetzales the night. It has restrooms.
El otro lugar que está registrado ya no acepta personas durmiendo en vans. Entonces nos quedamos a dormir en este parqueo, seguro con portón, cobran 100quetzales la noche. Hay servicio sanitario.

name: Hospedaje Xesuj Tsununa
description:
This is a small hospedaje 200-300 meters away from the Lago Atitlan. Right before Centro de Salud y Nutrizion Tsununa. There are 3 rooms, but we asked for camping as there is grassy area which can take up to 3-4 small tents(check photos). There is a number to contact the owner right at the entrance as he lives near the center of the village(see photo).

He gave us a price of 30 quetzales for three people per night(2 adults and 1 kid). There's a toilet and cold shower both in good condition. 

That's the cheapest we have found so far after being on the lake for almost 10 days. 

This place is more for backpackers. Also a small car/van can enter here though. 

The patio is clean and looks nice. As the owners rents the rooms for around 1200 quetzales per month they are occupied most of the time by travellers. There's a kitchen, but we haven't looked very much at it, though it seems dirty due to careless by people who rent the place. One of the guy renting here has a dog running around.

Overall OK place to spend several days exploring the area. 

The entrance gate does not have a locker. The owner said it is very quiet here, but we locked it around 10:00 pm with our own locker for more safety. During day there's a lot of tuk-tuks passing by as the road which is 100 m away from the hospedaje is the road which goes to the dock with the boats. After 9 pm it gets really calm and quiet. 

Some of the neighbors do not speak Spanish, only Kaq'chikel so if there is no one around you can ask them to contact owner if you do not own guatemalan number. This was our case. 

Happy travels.

name: Sabados y Domingo venta de comida
description:
We arrived in the village and look where to camp before doing the hiking alone, without guide. 

It was important one day acclimatization as we were going to hike with our 4 years old. 

We asked here to camp in the backyard of the store, which is on the left side on the road coming from direction Chimaltenango.

To put our tent they asked 50 quetzales we negotioted for 30 quetzales for all of us. Two adults/one child.

There is a clean toilet and shower. We didn't ask for the shower as we said during negotiation that we wouldn't use the hot shower as it was very cold. Maybe with hot shower price could go up.

They also serve food during weekends and during the night some people came over to eat. Also they rent two rooms, I think in quite good condition. From outside looked clean. Where people eat there is a stove though we didn't ask to use it. 

Overall calm place to spend one night before trekking. 

The entrance point for the hiking is really close to the place, maybe 3-4 minutes walking. 

You could also camp on top of the house/store which has a flat roof and the view is amazing. We didn't do there as it was raining. 

The brother of one of the guys who runs the place is renting equipment. We need backpack, but didn't rent as he asked for 75 quetzales per day. Across the street a place with banner "Guia Local Don Valeriano" also rents equipment. We rent backpack 70 litres in terrific condition for 50 quetzales for 2-3 days. The son of Don Valeriano is called David and he is also a guide. 

Happy travels.

name: Route to Flores
description:
If you are going from Semuc to Flores this route is not the best. This route is for 4x4 vehicles and there are warnings of people asking for money on the road. It’s better to go back to Coban and then turn to Flores, even when the route is supposed to be longer, because this street is completely paved.
---
Si va de Semuc Champey hacia Flores es mejor no tomar esta ruta porque la carretera es de piedra por muchos kms, es para vehículos 4x4 y también hay avisos de personas pidiendo peajes más adelante. Es mejor devolverse a Coban y de ahí desviarse hacia Flores, ya que esa calle sí está pavimentada aunque la ruta diga que es más larga.

name: Playa dorada
description: Parking by the lake without amenities 50 qtz to sleep pleasant asphalt road. Too bad the parking lot is average but the view is pleasant. Does not justify the detour

name: Refills - Somos Tierra
description: Bring your own containers to refill anything from flour to nuts, shampoos, hand sanitizer, eco cleaners, snacks, oils, vinegar. It’s great! Also sells natural soaps and bath stuff.

name: Custom cushions, upholstery, sewing
description: Tapiceria Miguel custom-made new cushions for our camper and did an awesome job! He has lots of fabrics to choose from, plus we bought some funky pattern at the market and he incorporated it! We gave him custom dimensions and he nailed it! Definitely recommend! It’s the blue building, don’t think there’s a sign. Check the photo for his whatsapp.

name: Space with grass to walk dogs
description: We found it really hard to let our dogs go to the bathroom in downtown Antigua because all of the green areas are fenced off. We found this great little stretch of dirt road with lots of grass and area for them to use the bathroom. Bring your own poop bags and keep it clean.

name: Vivero y Café de La Escalonia
description: Gorgeous garden setting with plants and water features, great coffee and great breakfast. Pet friendly on a leash. Huge selection of natural goodies in shop as well. Coffee q15, omelet q31, med smoothie q25.

name: Large parking area
description: There are 2 large parkings side by side. Allowed to camp in the rig for the night. Belongs to hotel next door that has security 24h. 50Q per night.

name: Next to potato fields
description:
I talked to several locals and they had no problem that I stay here. At night gets cold. People is super nice, all said hi and some stopped to talk with me, in the afternoon one of the neighbors came to tell me where he lives in case I need something and wish good night. You can rent bathroom for 2Q at lamas place in the village.
Also I recommend the ecological trail Piedra Cuache, from here go straight to the mountain.

name: Hostal del Angel
description:
As of the time of writing, it's a new hostal that isn't formerly opened yet. However, the owner (who also owns a restaurant right next door) let us park on the grounds for the night. 50q per person.

Beautiful spot with incredible views across the whole valley. Wonderful mountain air. We were given a key to use the bathrooms in one of the hostel rooms - though this may not happen for you if all the hostel rooms are full once it opens properly.

There are some sheep and some ducks and some rabbits and the staff are super friendly. They even proactively helped us level our vehicle.

Good WiFi. Electricity (if you have a very long cord). No Blackwater dumping. Good cell signal.

Up to full size Sprinter van would fit no problem. Big rigs may fit if you're a solid driver and are ok with backing out all the way - it's a bit narrow. Worth checking.

name: Public Parking Area on Lake Shore
description:
We followed the other parking indication close by to get here but discovered if we came another hundred meters towards the shore there was a grassy area outside of the chocked and parking lines of the official parking area. We spent two nights here and no one bothered us at all. Lots of locals pass by on foot and there’s lots of cars that arrive during the day but at night it was super quiet and felt very safe. 

Tons of free roaming dogs around but they got along just fine with our dogs. Incredible views of the lake! Walking distance to lots of little touristy shops and restaurants. Cross over the little foot bridge to the east and there are some really neat little beaches only a few minutes walk away.

name: church parking lot
description: basic gravel parking lot just next to the road. a bit noisy in the morning because of trucks climbing the road. but very fine for one night in the middle of nowhere. locals said it is very safe. nobody came, only few women crossing the way to the next village. enjoy!

name: Public Dock - narrow dead end street
description: If your rig is small enough like a minivan or small van you can make it to a parking spot right in front of a little grassy area right on the lake. It’s a little tricky to turn around as there is very limited space but if you can make it I highly recommend it! Absolutely gorgeous views. Felt really safe and quiet

name: CERNE women association
description: CERNE is a local association that works with women which suffer violence at home. They offer psycological and financial support as well as they teach them a job. They also coordinate with local police to protect them. The women work here to support themselves and produce very nice traditional clothes, which you can buy for a fair price. The shirts in the first picture are around 200-300 quetzales.

name: Taller de Rolando
description:
Rolando was recommended by a local from Huehuetenango who has a VW Beatle. He s a multi brand mechanic. I saw lot of cars there, mostly 4x4. He also has a lot of experience in VW classics as he had more that 20.

At the beginning he thought my kombi had a problem with a piston buton  making a deeper inspection detected the issue was in the clutch flywheel, simpler and cheaper.
In one day we lowered the engine, sent it to a turner and in the next day I was en route again. Honest, competent and fare prices.

He also allows you to sleep in the mechanic shop, he likes meeting travelers and has one of the best views that any other mechanic shop.
Phone: +502 3231 0848

name: Front of Pelicanos Hotel
description: The beach in front of the Pelicanos Hotel, near the wooden swing. The security guard may allow you to use the outdoor shower, as well as the bathroom and hammocks (this is not guaranteed). This is a public section of beach, so it is perfectly legal to camp here. We stayed here for a week and we had no issues with permissions or security. While we were there, we positioned logs that make a nice area to sit around a campfire. Bring mosquito repellent.

name: In front Hotel La casa del Lacandon
description:
We parked in the evening but we didn't stay in the van until night. 
We came to sleep at 8pm and nobody bored us.  Slept ok.

name: Palacio Municipal Morales Izabal
description:
We stop here for overnight, asked a policeman and he said was ok. 
There are some local  sellers, grocery, fastfood. 
During the day the transit starts early morning, but at night is quiet and safe.

name: public playa (signed)
description: This is a public area, with a small pull off on the side of the road for parking (2 or 3 cars would fit). trees for hammocks, bbq pits and a couple benches. i dont see any reason as to why you couldnt wild camp here but we just hung around for the afternoon. it is opposite posada del cerro

name: check point
description:
They asked us for our vehicle papers and passport, and they asked us questions. we saw that other cars were searched personally.
---
Nos pidieron los papeles del vehículo y el pasaporte, y nos hicieron preguntas. vimos que a otros autos les hicieron cateo personal.

name: Free parking
description:
It is a very wide spot with a few trees and palm trees, we met Neri, a man who lives at the end of the street and he told us that the land belongs to his friend and that there is no problem parking and spending the night here. Even Neri offered us to shower at her place.
About 50 meters away there is a street with a white fence that leads to the beach, but we are not recommended to stay parked between the street because cars pass by. He told us that it is very quiet and that in Monterico and Hawaii everything is more expensive and the parking lots charge, and also the beaches are more private with houses facing the sea.
---
Es un spot muy amplio con unos cuantos árboles y palmeras, conocimos a Neri un hombre que vive al fondo de la calle y nos dijo que el terreno es de su amigo y que no hay problema por parquear y pasar la noche aquí. Incluso Neri nos ofreció ducharnos en su casa. 
A unos 50 metros hay una calle con barda blanca que da para la playa pero no nos recomienda quedarnos parqueados entre la calle porque pasan autos. Nos dijo que es muy tranquilo y que en Monterico y Hawái es más caro todo y los parqueos cobran, y también las playas son más privadas con casas frente al mar.

name: Bomberos San Antonio
description: Friendly small Bomberos station. They let me store my bicycle safely and I could stay for the night on a folding bed in the kitchen/gym.

name: Hotel dulce sueña
description:
Friendly hotel near the bus terminal and the center. 70GTQ per person!

Français
hotel chaleureux prêt du terminal d'autobus et du centre. 70GTQ par personne !

name: Adventurous caves of B'omb'il Pek
description:
If you're looking for an adventure and a community project all in one, this is the place to go! These are two caves, B'omb'il Pek and Jul Iq' which you have to hike to for about 40 minutes. We liked it better than the Candelaria caves.

B'omb'il Pek is a cave you can access by an 85m rappel (or very steep, unprotected stairs). Once in the cave you can crawl your way into a part of the cave with small 1500 yo. carbon drawings (which are a little bit damaged by a cave exploration expedition..). 

The other cave Jul Iq' has some amazing structures and the light that enters the cave is just beautiful.

Guides use professional equipment and are trained by ex-military. The income from tourism benefits their community, they explained that over the years it supported the building of a school and common meeting area. They are open to tourists again after 2.5 years of covid closure. 

It's 75q pp to visit the cave and an extra 75q pp if you want to do the rappel. It's well worth it considering there'll be two guides and the tour is about 4 hours. Bring water, a snack and repellent. They need to know a day in advance, you can WhatsApp them (in Spanish) on +502-4998-7410.

name: Shaday Gasolinera
description:
Gas station with small shop.
They let me camp on the covered terrasse above the shop. Guarded parking for trucks too

name: Piedra de Cuache hike
description: Start of the short 2km hiking trail, just walk up through the fields. It was quite difficult to find any info on hikes in this National Park, so that's why we upload this one. The hike is pretty steep and it takes you about 1.5 hours in a leisurely pace, you can't get lost. Great views over Huehue and when skies are clear you can see the volcanoes.

name: De lo Alto Farms
description: Wifi. Restrooms. Showers. Campfires. Coffee tours.

name: De Lo Alto Farms
description: Great rainy night, have visited prior to this time, great hosts and beautiful enviroment

name: de lo alto Farms
description: Nice campsite, bathroom, shower, coffee farm

name: Camp AKT
description: Nice campground very close to Acatenango trailhead with tents for rent. Noce bathrooms and showers with hot water and electricity. Beautiful view of the valley with sunset over Atitlan volcano.

name: Restaurante Bahía San Pedro
description: Nice and Sécure spot on el Naranjo. In front of the River San Juan. Also there is a nice Hotel Bahía San Juan if you wnat to rest. The lady of the restaurant let us park free if we eat at her restaunt. The food was amazing and the restaurant also is beatifull over the River. Nice sunset. Good place after entering or going to el Ceibo.

name: Playa la punta
description: orilla del lago de peten itza con aguas cristalinas , restaurante , muelle , mesas , ranchitos y columpios precio por persona Q50.00  $6.25 USD

name: Hostel Iguana Azul
description:
Nice, small, quiet hostel a few blocks from the centro in Copan. Clean bathrooms, hot showers, free wifi, parking on the street in front of the hostel or a few motorcycles could be fit into a courtyard behind the locked gate. 
400 lempiras for a private room with shared bathroom for two per night.
Nice owner from the US.

name: D&D Brewery
description:
You now have to use the bare parking lot. No shade, nothing and publicly accessible. Price still the same though...

camping: 3.50 US$ pp

name: Luna Jaguar Hot Springs
description: A beautiful hot springs 20k down a dirt road from Copan Ruinas.  Series of 10-15 pools scattered throughout the jungle.  Although we didn't camp here, we asked the attendant and he said it is fine to camp in the parking lot for 100L/vehicle ($5).  Price: 100L/vehicle ($5).

name: Campamento
description: Camping at a hotel on the beach a few miles past Trujillo.  The hotel was unoccupied and they let us park the trucks between the hotel and the beach.  Onsite restaurant, bar and beautiful pool. Clean bathrooms, outdoor 'rinse' off shower, free, fairly fast wifi  Price: $12/night.

name: Omega Tours
description: Camped in the parking lot of the lodge and tour company.  Camping was free with purchase of rafting trip, well worth it!  Clean bathrooms, cold showers, free but slow wifi.  Price: Free

name: Margarita Beach Hotel
description: Decent, clean hotel set across the road from the beach.  Very buggy, right next to a marsh.  Room with 2 double beds, ensuite (smelly) bathroom with hot water showers and 4 people was $25/night.  Price: $25/night

name: Bayview Hotel
description: Small hotel right on the ocean.  Tiny, cramped bathrooms with hot water showers and fridge in rooms.  Supposed wifi that worked 1/8 of the time.  No kitchen, but the owner let us use her grill.    Price: $29/night.

name: La Tigra National Park Visitor Center San Juancito
description: A good alternative to staying in Tegucigalpa, although the entrance road to the visitors center was very steep and narrow.  Also some hairpin curves with unforgiving ditches. At the El Rosario visitor center they let us camp for free with access to the centers bathroom and showers, although we didn't try the showers.  Very small spaces, nothing much bigger then our rig could fit.  Free!  Price: Free

name: Hotel Gualiqueme
description: Hot ! Parking in hotel carpark. Shade is available. Swimming pool and bar/restaurant. WIFI from parking lot. US20 per night. 24hr security and just off PanAm. Water spigots in car park – no power. About halfway across Honduras if rushing across.

name: Texaco Copan
description:
Update 3/2020: User reports"They would not let us park there for the night in our truck but didn't give any reason. They were quite insistent that we had to leave. Maybe it is different with smaller campers."

A texaco station with a parking area out back that they let you camp in. Very close to Copan. They have restrooms, non potable water, and even purified water (5 gallon jugs) for only 20L. We heard from friends you can even plugin here for some electricity (check near the coke machines). For a gas station, its really nice!  Charged us 100L for a night.

name: Sol De Copan
description: Delicious beer and food. We had the Salchicha (homemade sausages) and escalope (schnitzel), 130L and 180L respectively. Beer is home brewed, when we visited there was a hefeweizen and a dark lager, 75L for a half liter. Wine, white and red, is also available.

name: Las Arenas
description: A small camping area at the end of a football pitch. This is right across from Copan. There are a couple guest houses nearby with showers that we were able to use, and bathrooms as well. Price was 150L.

name: Finca Paradise - Bioesfera
description:
A finca near D&D brewery with a lot more room for camping. 9 dollar per person per night. Pool, showers, a beautiful garden and more. Places for tent campers on the grass. Big rigs might fit in here but it would be a tight squeeze. Wifi available. Electricity outlets available at the base of the light poles. Bring an extension cord. 



UPDATE JULY 2018: now called Bio Paradise - signs lead you all the way.  Don’t look for a finca sign.

name: Pulhapanzak Waterfalls
description: Amazing waterfall and pools. Great way to cool off on a hot day. Camping is allowed in the parking for truck campers but if you have a tent there is a special area with views of the falls!  Price was 280 per night for 2 people, which included entrance to the park. Highly recommend the hike behind the waterfall. It is amazeballs!

name: Paradise Found
description: A hotel on the beach about 15k east of la ceiba. Spent a night here and then caught a ferry to Utila the next morning. Good food but rooms were filthy and run down. May be able to camp here; not much room for big rigs though. We could not fit through gates.

name: La Ceiba Ferry Terminal
description: Caught the ferry here to Utila. They go to Roatan as well. Price for a one way ticket to Utila was $28 USD. You van pribably camp in the parking lot here if you are desperate. Parking was $115L per day.

name: The Lighthouse
description: An anazing hotel over the water in the bay. Super clean rooms and great wifi. Amazing spot to relax after diving. We loved it here!

name: Utila Dive Center
description:
Great dive shop in utila. 
http://www.utiladivecenter.com/en/

name: Finca Las Glorias
description: Lakefront hotel / restaurant with secure parking for our truck camper.  Dogs allowed.  Swimming pool, wifi, electricity, showers, 200 lempiras per night.

name: Aguas Termales
description: Camping area is basically a parking/rest area near some pools. You can walk to hot springs. Family who runs the place is extremely friendly. 100L per person per night.

name: Balneario San Francisco
description: A swimming pool, play ground, football pitch, camping area and more. Nice place to break up the drive from the coast or the lake to the Nicaragua border. Paid 150L per person which included entrance to the swimming pools.

name: Finca Bavaria
description: Finca Bavaria is located in the city center, and let you camp on their property. A friendly old man was taking care of the place when we were there, and they have a restaurant. We went into town for dinner, and it was a really nice little town. Feelt safe, and there were plenty of restaurants and some grocery stores.   Price: 200 Lempiras

name: Hotel La Esperanza
description: We were looking for a place to camp, and we'd heard that people had been allowed to camp in this hotel's fenced parking lot. Not so this time. We asked several of the hotels in town, but the only place that would let us camp was the local Texaco gas station in the city center. Too noicy and too crowded for us in our roof top tent, so we decided to check in to a room.   Price: 280 Lempiras

name: Balneario Valle Escondido
description: Small Meadow Court, no infrastructure, a lot of dogs barking at night and some traffic.     Lempia 150.00 / night without bathrooms  Directly on the road CA 14

name: Thermas Balneario del Rio
description:
Wohlfühlplatz on meadow, showers and toilets. 5 hot thermal baths of 32-40 degrees. very quiet.     Lempia 240.00 / night incl baths     (avoid weekends and holidays!)  Km 7 Carretera a Santa Rosa, before Gracias Lempira

a perfect place for some days longer to stay. you can rent a cabana etc., or we stayed here in our own motorhome 300p/n, power extra. The pools are clean and have div. warm temperatures. :-)). erverything is very well maintained. the staff is very nice and some speak english. you will enjoy the place.
May 2019: Price is 240L per person

name: Restaurant Sabor Latino
description: Good overnight place on meadow, beach, sea clean and good for swimming, pretty quiet.     free, but it is expected that you consume something in the restaurant.  On the Caribbean, near Puerto Cortes

name: Botanical Garden "Lacentilla"
description: Good to stay overnight in the great botanical garden. Otherwise no toilet available infrastructure. Quiet. 300.00 Lempira / Admission and night  South of Tela

name: Park Touristico
description: Beautiful picnic area in the pine forest with covered picnic and barbecue areas. Quiet. Pool available, but only open on Sundays. Lempira 60L pp / night.  Valle de Angeles, about 30 km from Tegucigalpa

name: Casa Alemania
description: Good place to lawn, right on the beach, toilets and showers, water, wifi. Good food, Gunther and Paula cook many delicious European food on request. Swimming pool and washing machines, quiet.     Lempira 200.00 / night, from the 7th Night, it still costs Lempira 100.00 / night.  On the Caribbean side, Trujillo

name: Football Danli
description: Good to go to camp overnight next day across the border to Nicaragua. No infrastructure. Pretty quiet at night.  After supermarket "El Colonial" ca.1.5 miles, right side

name: El Rincon del Toro
description:
- camping behind a restaurant
- not a bad place, but nothing to write home about
- free
- bathrooms (water did not work)
- the place was partially lit 
- gate was somehow closed (fastened with a piece of rope)
- there was no fence, so anybody could walk in there
- pizza was ok, the whole place looked nice, but the service was quite bad
- generally an emergency place to stay if you are headed to Las Manos border and it is getting late

name: Taller Ochoa
description: Legit for a little shop in Pena Blanca. We had some minor work done here. There are several auto parts stores in town, too.

name: El Pital
description: $10 for empty lot on top of the mountain, beautiful views, and very quiet. 4wd required and 1+hr off the highway. Just follow the signs for el pital until you're on top of the mountain.

name: Don Miguel Hotel and Restaurant
description: They let us park and camp in their gated lot as long as we bought dinner. Super nice owner speaks perfect English and was very welcoming. Dinner was good too! Toilets available while restaurant was open.

name: Helen's Hotel And Restaurante
description:
Big shady lot with gate that's closed at night. Beach access from hotel. Free, but we purchased a meal. Really great place to stay before heading to islands.

Edit: Now charges 200L per car...

name: Galaxy Wave Ferry
description: Travelled here from La Ceiba, left our car in the secure lot, and stayed at a house through Roatans Backpacker hostel. Our dog rode in crate and cost $350L each way, he was able to ride with us to Utila and only cost $100L each way.

name: Grissy`s Hotel and Hostel
description:
Hotel, Hostel and RV-Camping up to 25 foot, we stayed at the lawn close to the pool,The owner and staff is very friendly, most of them speak english language, the Restaurant offers good food for all prices,  free Internet was very fast and a good thing ... they have a coin operated  washingmachine. A Taxitransport in town was less than 2 $,
Walking to the beach was only 50 meters,

name: Casona del Valle
description:
Beautiful restaurant with ideal location at km 28 of hwy 6 between Tegucigalpa and Danli. Mario and Graciela, the owners, welcomed us warmly and let us park on a level concrete pad in the secured/guarded parking lot behind the restaurant with all night access to the bathrooms.

We spoiled ourselves with a pizza de la casa (their speciality). Definitively the best pizza in Honduras!

The place is as awesome as any resort you can find...Anywhere! Highly recommended!

Only downside was no showers

name: Bueno Veterinario
description: Animal hospital, where we picked up heartworm medicine for our dog.

name: dentist
description: Claudia Zelaya, dentist. Decent dental work for a fraction of the North American prices. This is a good place to catch up with neglected dental work.

name: Cerro Azul-Meambar NP (Pancam lodge)
description: Truly stunning and quiet National Park. Ok, will admit we never camped here but only because we didn't know you could before we went. Wen't for a great walk up into the cloud Forrest. On the way out I asked about camping and they have a camping area there. They quoted me 100lps per person per night in a tent and it seems to have great views over the valley. They have dorm rooms (250lps). They don't have cooking facilities but no idea if they would let you use your own. Bobby who own D&D Brewery (where we found out about it) thinks it's the best NP in Honduras. The drive up is reasonably tough....  We have an SUV which doesn't have 4x4 and it was ok but steep in places - that said it didn't rain but being cloud Forrest apparently it does rain a bit. Lots of loose gravel, steep in places and needs a little bit of clearance. Doubt big rigs could do it but never drove one!

name: Mechanic Freddy Umberto Bonilla Gomez
description: While driving this remote road (very bad condition) we had a problem with the van. Luckily we found local mechanic in Lauterique village. He worked with us till late at night and then in the morning, and helped us to get back on the road. Very friendly and welcoming family, we spent a night in front of their house. Mechanic has experience with land rover, BMW, Nissan, Chrysler; speaks few words of English. He asked for 50 USD at the end.

name: Camping By The River
description: Free. Leveled open ground by the small river. There is a clear road after the bridge to the right (traveling North) off the main highway. The unpaved road goes for about 500 -1000 m until it comes to this open space. When we came locals were fishing and hanging out, they told us it's safe to stay here for a night plus brought us firewood to help us make our grill for the evening.  Not the prettiest spot, but we enjoyed it more than a service station, plus there's jungle around and green mountains in the backdrop.  Quiet night, in the morning heavy machinery appeared to do some excavation work.

name: Real Vista Hermosa
description: Paid L1300 for a double room, plus L200 for the dog. Closest hotel to the Border right on the highway. Classy place with pool, restaurant etc. and a bathroom about 10 times the size of our camper. Very clean. TV and AC. There is locked parking lot at the back, security out front. We had to whine to get the dog in our room.

name: Hotel Quinta Alejandra
description: overlander friendly, pool , showers, electric 110v. secure large villa, pet friendly. 200 limperas per nite all inc phone #9830-0721 or 3228-8123

name: Aqua Park Hacienda El Jaral
description: very pleasant spot for the first day in Honduras. Large grassy field in front of the Balneario. The camping fee of $ 7 / person includes the admission fee for the Balneario. Clean toilets, cold outdoor showers. It's about five minutes by car to the ruins of Copan.  Alternative campsite:  Right next to the parking lot of the archeological site you can camp behind the Texaco gas station for 50 Lempira / day.  ($ 7 / person)

name: Balneario Aguas Termales (Hot Springs)Presidente
description: Night in the parking lot above the Balnearios (free). To use the Balnearios a 30 or 50 Lempira / person admission fee must be paid. The Balneario is made very appealing, has great hot pools and toilets. The parking for the car was not ideal, because  we had the feeling that half the population of the village was walking by at night.  Good base to visit the pottery village of La Campa (about an hour drive).

name: Roli's Place
description: Beautiful backpacker hostel with huge garden area. Located in the center and only 80 m to the Caribbean sea. Bathroom with cold shower and toilet. Free WIFI. Free rental of bicycles and canoes. Free potable water. Beautiful and very well kept garden to hang out with open kitchen, covered dining area, hammocks, table tennis.  To the fort of San Fernando it's just a 5 minutes walk ($ 4.50 / person), one hour to the waterfall El Chorro.

name: Hotel La Hacienda
description: Not a classic campsite, but a good example of how to find a safe place to stay for the night. We asked at the front desk of a large hotel with secure parking lot if we could stay there. The answer at the front desk was "No". We then insisted a little pushy that we came "all the way from Germany" to here. Thereafter the boss was called who had no problem to let us camp overnight for free. Clean toilets, free WIFI.

name: Freizeitpark El Florida
description: Great campspot in a small pine forest in the equestrian and recreation park. Small zoo with sheep, deer, tapir, parrots and macaws right next to the site. Clean toilets and cold showers. Small pool. Very good restaurant with Honduran specialties. Mila, the Czech owner (?) let us camp for free but thought a tip of 100 Lempira for the night guardian was as appropriate.  Good base to visit the La Tigra National Park and the old mining town of Santa Lucia.

name: Villa Alejandra
description: Camping next to the pool behind a small hotel just before Danli. Located on the hillside and far from the noisy main road. Clean bathroom with cold shower. Extremely friendly, elderly owner: Mario Alfredo. Unfortunately the pool was painted so we could not use it. Covered poolside seating.

name: Hotel Palacio Real
description: $300 L for 2 people, 1 dog per night.   Looks shabby from the street but the rooms are big and clean, no a/c, no wifi.   The reception seems to close early, around dusk, maybe 6ish.   The parking area is gated.

name: Cabanas Los Pinos Mountain Resort
description: Beautifully landscaped resort. We asked to eat in the restaurant and park in the bottom lot. They were very friendly and said no problem. We were here in the low season so they may get too full in high season to allow for camping in the lot.

name: Aqua Splash
description: They allowed us to camp here for one night. Free. On parking lot. The Aqua park costs 170 lempiras per person. We did not use it. Safe. Guarded and locked gates at night.

name: Car Parts For VW La Meta
description: We found plenty of parts for our vw bus that couldn't find in Guatemala. You can also ask for mechanics here

name: hotel cadatur
description: Enclosed parking for bikes or car or small van. Maybe clearance issue on gate for bigger vehicles. Friendly owner half German half Honduran speaks Inglis

name: El Amatillo, El Salvador to El Amatillo, Honduras
description:
Normal crossing procedures but can be slow. Very friendly and professional officials

Make sure you have originals and COPIES of all your documents.

park on bridge and walk to yellow hut on right to show vax cert so you can pass. 

Complete online prechequeo up to 3 days before crossing. 35usd for vehicle. 3usd for passport. ask for receipts (boleto)

Addition just for dogs... make sure you declare your dogs here at the SEPA and get the paperwork with the stamp. when we came through and got our tip they did a quick visual inspection and saw we had dogs but didn't seem interested in charging us to enter. but you will absolutely need this paper at the border to leave Honduras. they wanted us to drive all of the way back to the border station we crossed at to get it. but with some pleading they allowed us to fill out the proper papers and get them stamped without the long drive back. we were told we needed that exit paper for the dogs from Honduras to get the paperwork done at the IPSA, but Nicaragua didn't ask to see the old papers.

name: El Poy, El Salvador to Antigua Octopeque, Honduras
description:
El Salvador into Honduras.  Exit El Salvador: - First Aduana, . No costs. Just hand over the Temporary Import permit and they'll cancel it. - Then Immigration. Again, they just check you out of the system. No stamps in passport, only at airports and seaports (CA4).  

Into Honduras: - First Immigration: 3$ pp entry tax, receipt is handed over. - Then Aduana for the vehiocles. Slow process. Get the paperwork done, then  pay the fees at the bank (L712 per motorcycle = 35$) and then back to Aduana. Needs 2 copies of everything.   

Update 10/2021: We could pay directly at the office in cash (Lempiras only) and didn't need any copies of anything). Got stamps in both passports and an extra stamp for the vehicle.

Update: We paid L782 for a 2021 Jeep Gladiator. We had to provide exact change because they didn’t have change.

name: Balneario L.M. Hot Spring/Cabanas
description: Looks like a run down place but people are very friendly. A Cabana with WC for 300 Lempiras per night for one person, 350 for two. Cabana immediately on the hotspring (incl. in price) so you don't need a shower. Springwater is 30 degrees Celcius. Simple restaurant services. No wifi, signal 10 meters higher on the road. Bring a mosquito net. Access is very steep but concrete/rocks.

name: Mados Hotel Guanacaste, Choluteca
description: Decent hotel if you want to break up the drive through Honduras... On a Friday night he quoted us 750L with a receipt or 600L without... In dollars he wanted to charge us $30 without receipt (20L/$1) but we got him down to $25 for the night mentioning we were just passing through to Nicaragua and wouldn't be using the pool. Good WiFi connection, security and parking in the patio, includes A/C and TV.

name: Hotel Granja Delia
description: Good hotel while pricy it has buffet breakfast, huge room a/c, warm good showers, handy supermarket next doors. We had a rough journey as got lost so it was a great stop to recharge. Parking for big RV cost $929L two people

name: Steakhouse de Montaña
description: We asked if we could park in the parking lot behind gate for the night and have dinner at the restaurant. Restaurant happened to be closed that day but it was no problem to stay the night. No charge! We could use the very nicely decorated bathroom, very clean too. There was a guard dog at the gate during the night. Very quiet night. English is spoken. The restaurant is at the entrance of the little town Santa Lucia on the right side of the road.

name: Puerto Cortes
description:
In the parking lot of the playa puplica facing the hotel Villa del Sol, facing the sea, quiet at night. 

Sur le parking de la playa puplica face à l'hotel Villa del Sol, face à la mer, tranquille la nuit.

name: La Tela
description:
On the free wifi free beach of the municipality, WC and shower, clean beach 

Sur la plage gratuit tranquille wifi de la municipalité, WC et douche payante, plage propre

name: Sambo Creek
description:
Parking at the Hotel Canadien 100L at night you can use the toilet 

Parking de l'hôtel Canadien 100L la nuit possibilite d'utiliser les WC

name: Santa Rita
description:
In the street next to the central park and next to the town hall super quiet wifi city tap water on the square 

Dans la rue à côté du parque central et à côté de la mairie super tranquille wifi de la ville robinet d'eau sur la place

name: La Esperanza
description:
In Calle 8 next to the hotel posada (wifi code posada20) right next to the central park and the national police 

Dans la calle 8 à côté de l'hôtel posada (code wifi posada20) juste à côté du parque central et de la police nationale

name: Santa Rosa De Copan
description:
Parqueo y banos 100l per night next to the city center friendly owner would extend secure 

Parqueo y banos 100l par nuit à côté du centre ville proprietaire sympathique étendrait sécurisé

name: Puma Gas Station
description: We needed to stop between Guatemala and Nicaragua and were too cheap to pay for a hotel. This gas station did the trick. The attendants were nice as was the shotgun carrying guard who works all night. There are bathrooms and a mini-mart. No charge to stay.

name: Centro Campestre El Potrillo
description: Driving from Choluteca to El Espino (border between HN and NI), just before the town of San Marcos de Colón on the left side lies El Potrillo.  It is a horse riding facility with cabins, pool and a restaurant.  We had to stay there due to issues with my vehicle papers, which we sorted out with a lawyer in San Marcos de Colón.

name: Parque Nacional Montaña de Celaque
description: Parking next to visitor center. Beautiful park with hiking trails. All facilities brand new. Road steep but mostly paved. Very quiet. Picknick area and new restrooms. Entrance 120 lemp. per person plus 100 l . for camping.  No wifi, no Claro signal.

name: Oasis Colonial Hotel
description:
pretty nice and easy, close from crossing border and for 4 of us room with AC with huge pool and restaurant was 40 USD and they are pet friendly. you could possibly ask about camping, it was really hot so we checked in :)
Parking Of Hotel Swimmingpool OASIS COLONIAL 30km After El Salvador On The Panamerican

name: canopy extremo
description: canopy extremo, 6 lines, looks fantastic! had been there at semana santa and because we had been the only tourists besides approx. 30 hondurians they tried to charge us 700 lempiras instead of 500. so because of that and the very long waiting time we deceided to leave but it looks like huge fun. last km is very steep, have fun.

name: Colonial city center
description:
Beautiful square. 

Nice placa with church
You can go up the oldest clock tower from america and have a nice view. 30 pP.

name: Campamento Palabra de Vida
description:
From user - "The owner Romeo welcomed us with pleasure. We were able to use the toilets, the hot showers and a little wifi. Very calm, no tobacco or alcohol inside. "

huge fenced property in the mountains with guesthouses, soccerfields, basketball, pool, minigolf and even paintball (!?), not really a campsite - actually this is a holiday-camp for young christians, highseason in january, when we were here, there was only a small groop of US-American volunteers
we asked the (english-speaking) staff to stay for one night on this beautiful property, after a short while they said yes, but excused that there's nothing to offer us - no problem, we have everything in our van!
parked next to one of the guesthouses, then the super friendly and welcoming staff came again and showed us a clean bathroom with cold shower and even a small room with double bed to use, invited us for coffee and breakfast next morning
wonderful people, cool and calm night, one of our best stays in Honduras! Price: for free :)

name: Caseta de peaje / toll gate
description:
Clean toilet and clean shower. 
Police 24 hours. 
We stop here 5 p.m. only to sleep.
There is a big pavimented plan area to park our car.

name: El Bosque Hotel and Overlander Camp
description:
we could camp on the large hotel property wherever we wanted to put our camper, which was nice to get a bit away from the highway. we could use the office toilet (closed after 10pm), after 10pm you can probably use the ones in the restaurant, ask the night guard. no showers (showers on request). water faucets around. slow but OK WiFi.
150L (2021: now 200L) two People in car. Shower this same up.

name: Uno petrol station
description: They allowed us to sleep there. quite gas station with lots of space. They close at 10 pm but there is a security guard all night. there is a restaurant with wifi. very kind all the staff. and free! they are going to open shop, bar and toilets soon.

name: Pupuseria Mary
description: great restaurant!!! from 15 to 25 each papusa. great meal!!! good wifi!! Don't miss it, typical food!!!-

name: triunfo de la cruz
description:
Excellent place to camp is free right on the seafront ask for Mrs. Petrona is located in the Garifuna community very good people and the food very delicious 

excelente lugar para campar es gratis justo a la orilla del mar preguntar por  señora Petrona esta situado en la comunidad garifuna muy buenas personas y la comida muy riquísima

name: Valle De Angeles
description: Large flat dirt parking lot in town. It's 20 lempira to park for the day or 40 to park for the day and night. It is guarded all night and is very quiet at night, even on a Friday night.

name: Hospedaje El Mirador
description: Great place and alternative place to stay. They have a room that is $100L for the night with no bathroom but your car or motorcycle is safe behind a huge gate they close around 10pm.  Room is nice and basic has everything you need like a bed to sleep in and peace of mind your vehicle is safe. Police and military patrol the area day and night so it's super safe :)

name: Tropigas
description: The only place I could find in Tegucigalpa that could refill my US propane tank. It was also the quickest refill I've had out of 5 in Central America. In and out in less than 10 minutes. Coat for a 20lb tank was 170 lempiras.

name: Alineamiento M y G
description: Excellent mechanic. I was told they were the best and cheapest in town and I believe it. Problem is they don't carry many parts. But they were VERY helpful tracking down the bearings I needed for a 97 Dodge Ram. The owner even drove me around to pick the parts up. Highly recommended.

name: Texaco. Possible to overnight
description: Texaco gas station with foodmart. Foodmart is closed at 21:00. Possible to stay at guarded (all night) parking.

name: Camping at the Beach - Free
description: We asked the restaurant if it's ok to stay overnight right next to it at the beach. They said it's ok and were a bit surprised we are sleeping inside a van and also gave them a small tip. The restaurant had good fish! Pretty hot if there is no breeze. There is also a restroom and outside showers by the restaurant, I think it's ok to use them and it's open all night.

name: Captain Morgan
description: Laid back hostel with friendly staff. Good and quick responses via email. Dorm room 10US (if you dive it's 7US that day), only with fan, free wifi. If you want AC it's an additional 15 US per day/divided by people in room that want it. There are also private rooms available. If you do a dive course (we did open water) for 288 US you get 4 nights for free. Dogs are welcome, but not allowed in the rooms. Our pup was hanging out anywhere else and liked the place. When we were diving we left him at the hostel outside. Street dogs come and go, but are friendly. Especially if you travel with a dog it's a great place to go.

name: pico bonito
description:
You can camp to the river Oria ask for Don Oudulio Calix or Chepe Nuñez a very good people the payment per person is 35 lempiras very good place you can make campfire and cook in it a good experience sleep with the sound of the river .. I recommend 100% 

se puede acampar a la Oria del rio preguntar por Don Oudulio Calix  o Chepe Nuñez unas muy buenas personas  el pago por persona es de 35 lempiras  muy buen lugar se puede hacer fogata y cocinar en ella una buena experiencia dormir con el sonido del rio .. lo recomiendo 100%

name: Mango Inn
description: Tuesday pizza night - buy any pizza and get the second for free. Really good wood fire pizza! Margarita 220lp plus 30 per extra topping.

name: Hotel Posada Del Valle
description: Ok place to stay. We weren't allowed to camp in the parking lot so we had to take a room as it was very late already. Cheapest Room with ac 416lp, with fan 297. Dogs are allowed if they don't bark the reception lady said.

name: Centro Turistico Guayapito
description: Free! Asked at the restaurant to park for the night and they allowed us to camp at the parking lot between restaurant and piscina. Clean Washrooms are outside and open all night. We did get breakfast in the morning for 20lp each (egg, beans, cheese and tortillas) and 5lp per cup of coffee but it was not on the menu. The temperature at night was great to sleep.

name: Soccer Field
description: Camped next to the soccer field. There are some trees for shade and you are kinda hidden from the road. The next day the police showed up. They were very friendly and wanted to see the import permit and car registration. They were talking with us (the little bit of spanish we spoke) and were curious about the set up in our van. After a while they left us alone to finish making coffee and packing up to head for the border

name: Posada Del Mar
description:
ADMIN NOTE: Opening this place again - see check-in from the June 9th, 2018. "It's directly next to the Hotel y Cabanas Playa Caribe..."

Beautiful property with nice clean pool. Lounge area, cabins to rent. Electricity if you have a long enough extension. Outside showers. Clean restrooms. 50 meters from the beach. View of the beach from the pool. BBQ place. Security at night. The owner François is really welcoming. Call Abel Saavedra at +50496589808 so he can help you get boat tours to Punta Sal (Janette Kawas) National Park. We loved this place. 300 L per vehicle to camp. $15 USD best deal for what you get in town.

name: Miami - Coastal Village
description: Beach front camping by the home of Alejandro Alas. 100L per night. Basic facilities. You can get the most affordable boat tours to Laguna de Los Micos and the beautiful Punta Sal (Jannette Kawas) National Park from especially if you get a bigger group. For boat tours ask for or call German Aguero at +50496072311 or Abel Saavedra in Tela +50487689410. 4x4 Recommended.

name: Familia Velazquez (Avelio/Bertilia)
description: Wow, not enough incredible things to say about this place and these people. The adventure starts the moment you hit the dirt road in San Geronimo and drive 20kms through the mountains of Parque Nacional Montaña de Comayagua to reach the community of Rio Negro (4x4 and high clearance highly recommended). The Velazquez Family owns an organic coffee farm (the brother of Avelio sells it in Minnesota!) and have opened up their beautiful land to folks to camp on. 75L per car per night. No bathrooms for campers (yet!) but they can open up one of their cabanas for you to use, if needed. No wifi but they do have electricity (not at sites). As of now, there are two areas to camp - near the river or at "the vista," which is flat and has an incredible view of the valley. Bertilia, the wife of Avelio, is also a great cook (vegetarian chorizo!) and offers breakfast, lunch, and dinner for an extra cost. And when you're wanting something active, you can take a hike through dense forest up to two waterfalls: Los Ensueños (50 min) and La Gavilán (1.5 hours and ~70m tall!!). No need for a guide - the trail is well-marked. We spent here 4 wonderful nights here and when we weren't outside enjoying the forest we were drinking coffee w our new friends in their kitchen :)

name: Parking lot by Pollolandia
description: Parking by Pollolandia next to Gas station. Safe. Free.

name: Jungle River Lodge
description: Great place by the Cangrejal River. Only one leveled spot for a mid size rig if you're camping. $12 USD per vehicle per night. Cabins, rooms and a home available for rent. Great views, superb rafting, nice zip-line. Close access to hikes in Pico Bonito National Park. Very nice hang out / bar restaurant area with view of the river. Nice and refreshing river pools. Oscar, the owner, is very friendly and accommodating. We recommend rafting and canyoning with Juan Carlos. You can do canyoning only when water levels are down. We had an amazing time!!! Don't let the simple looks of this place be deceiving. It is a little gem and very affordable. Fast internet, nice showers and restrooms. Staff is also super nice. To check for availability email Oscar at jungleriverlodge@gmail.com

name: Cesar Mariscos Hotel & Restaurante
description: The heat wore us out pretty fast so we decided it was finally a good opportunity for some legit "hotel time." They have two hotels: this one (~$70/night with breakfast) and the "annex" which is 3 blocks away and a little cheaper (~$50/night no breakfast but all the same facilities as here). Secure and guarded parking lot for our car around was the corner. Tela is a bit grungy but we were super happy with this place - clean, cozy (w really comfy beds!), friendly, and has a pool!

name: Alton's Dive Center & Hostel
description: Great dive shop away from the hustle and bustle. Super friendly staff and definitely one of the quietest hostels on the island (they stop serving alcohol at 7pm). We did our advanced cert here because we couldn't pass on the $275 special they were having. "Fun" dives are also very cheap ($35/tank). The accommodations aren't the nicest but it wasn't much of a problem because we were outside or diving most of the time anyway. Has a kitchen (with big fridge) for guests to use, wifi, etc. Lots of sand flies on the island - bring baby oil!!

name: TranquilSeas Eco Lodge & Dive Center
description: This beautiful and sustainsble eco lodge has killer views and the owner, Chris is a fellow overlanding enthusiast. If you are looking to treat yourself in paradise you should check out their website to book a cabana at tranquilseas.com. If you are planning an extended stay on the island, ferrying your vehicle over may make sense. There are a lot of places to explore on the island, so a vehicle is necessary. If you ferry over with your vehicle, Chris may acommodate you to park on his property. Email him directly at tranquilseashotel@gmail.com. They also rent paddle boards, kayaks and have a lovely patio restaurant/bar and pool. A great place to stay or stop by in Roatan!

name: La Villa de Soledad B&B
description: A really lovely spot right across the road from (or ON) the Rio Cangrejal. We weren't super excited about the options in this area (because most of the places barely have space for a car) so we decided to inquire here and are so glad we did! They're technically a B&B but, depending on how busy they are, the owner, John, will allow you to camp on his beautiful, flat, and spacious property. (Or if it's time to splurge and relax in a hotel, this is the place to do it!) But if you decide to camp, you have two options: Up the driveway (4x4 required!) near the main building which has electricity, bathrooms, wifi, and running water ($6 per person per night). OR he also owns the grassy patch of land at the bottom of the driveway that does *not* require 4x4 and is essentially on the river but there is no bathroom, electricity, etc. (Not sure how much he would charge for this)

name: Hotel Casa Real
description:
Very quiet place with big bedrooms large parking lot.
Very nice pool. 
They don't allow to sleep in your RV.

name: Parque Nacional La Muralla
description: Camped on our vehicle right next to the visitor center. 25 Lempira per person for park entrance fee. Free camping. Cabins / dorms available for 300 for two people. Restrooms and electricity in the visitor center cabin which is closed at night. There's a park guard who also guides hikes at 6-7 in the morning. There are 4 hike of different lengths to choose from. From the little town of La Union drive up the road to the park 14 km. The road is gravel but in ok condition. 4x4 may be needed during the rainy season.

name: Aldea El Guayabo
description:
This is a small village deep in the woods. Very warm people that like to talk and to know new people. I stay in the soccer field that belong to the community.
Very steep hills and 4x4 is needed.

name: Picnic spot on a creek
description: Nice spot to have lunch and a swim. The locals love it on wknds. Nigth very quiet.

name: Laguna San Julian, Mujeres Emprendedoras
description: 20 kilometers away from Danli, a very nice, quiet and safe place, large área that you can choose where to camp at the shore of the lagoon. If nobody is in the office you can continue 1 mile and ask for "Yanixa de el grupo de mujeres emprendedoras" in the nearest houses or call to +504-9909-9753 or +504-9676-0925. To enter you need to pay 1 dollar/person and to camp are 10 dollars/car but you can pay less if you talk with them.

name: Hotel Puerto Real
description: Upper market hotel with clean rooms, AC, big TVs, bar and restaurant (not open when we were here on a Monday), big pool (not really clean) and big secure parking right outside of rooms. A little expensive (750L for a room for the night) but well located right on the CA1 highway. Great place for the night between border crossings.

name: Pico Bonito
description:
Very nice place, boss Richard is English and likes to talk a lot with travelers. Swimming pool overflowing overlooking the river with a waterfall at the bottom. During the night possibility to park inside (big rig max 24 ft). Hot and clean showers. Good Wifi. Excellent food (the best camarones you've ever eaten!) All the same $ 15 per course. Parking, showers, swimming pool free by eating. There are three dogs on site but the pet owner acctroisles. Drinking water available.


Très bel endroit, le patron Richard est Anglais et aime beaucoup parler avec les voyageurs. Piscine a débordement donnant sur le rio avec au fond une cascade. Durant la nuit possibilité de se garer a linterieur (big rig max 24 ft). Douches chaudes et propres. Bon Wifi.
